div.p: This article surveys the recent developments in computational methods for second order fully nonlinear partial differential equations (PDEs), a relatively new subarea within numerical PDEs. Due to their ever increasing importance in mathematics itself (e.g., differential geometry and PDEs) and in many scientific and engineering fields (e.g., astrophysics, geostrophic fluid dynamics, grid generation, image processing, optimal transport, meteorology, mathematical finance, and optimal control), numerical solutions to fully nonlinear second order PDEs have garnered a great deal of interest from the numerical PDE and scientific communities. Significant progress has been made for this class of problems in the past few years, but many problems still remain open. This article intends to introduce these current advancements and new results to the SIAM community and generate more interest in numerical methods for fully nonlinear PDEs.

solutions to the underlying application problems depend on the solutions to their governing PDEs, analyzing and solving these PDEs has been critically important for the resolutions of many scientific and engineering application problems. To quote the renowned physicist and Nobel laureate Werner Heisenberg, "the progress of physics will to a large extent depend on the progress of nonlinear mathematics, of methods to solve nonlinear equations. . . and therefore we can learn by comparing different nonlinear problems."

Using nonlinearity as a criterion, PDEs can be divided into two categories: linear PDEs and nonlinear PDEs (cf. [76,166,167,168]). In the nonlinear category, PDEs are further classified as semilinear PDEs, quasi-linear PDEs, and fully nonlinear PDEs based on the degree of the nonlinearity. A semilinear PDE is a differential equation that is nonlinear in the unknown function but linear in all its partial derivatives. The nonlinear Poisson equation -Δu = f (u) is a well-known example of this class of PDEs. A quasi-linear PDE is one that is nonlinear in (at least) one of the lower order derivatives but linear in the highest order derivative(s) of the unknown function. A prototypical example of a quasi-linear PDE is the p-Laplace equation -div (|∇u| p-2 ∇u) = f (p = 2). Fully nonlinear PDEs are referred to as the class of nonlinear PDEs which are nonlinear in the highest order derivatives of the unknown function. General fully nonlinear first order PDEs have the form H[u](x) := H(∇u(x), u(x), x) = 0. The best-known examples include the Eikonal equation |∇u| = f and the Hamilton-Jacobi equation H(∇u) = 0. General fully nonlinear second order PDEs take the form F [u](x) := F (D 2 u(x), ∇u(x), u(x), x) = 0, (1.1) where D 2 u(x) denotes the Hessian matrix of u at x. Some well-known examples of this class include the Monge-Ampère equation F [u] := fdet(D 2 u) = 0, where det(D 2 u) denotes the determinant of D 2 u, and the Bellman equation F [u] := sup ν∈V (L ν uf ν ) = 0, where {L ν } ν is a family of second order linear differential operators (cf. [93]).

Fully nonlinear second order PDEs arise from many fields in science and engineering such as astrophysics, antenna design, differential geometry, geostrophic fluid dynamics, image processing, materials science, mathematical finance, mesh generation, meteorology, optimal transport, and stochastic control (cf. [3,45,19,93,88,90,103,110,137,176] and the references therein). Besides the need for developing deep and sophisticated analytical methods for analyzing this class of PDEs, there is an ever increasing demand for efficient and reliable numerical methods for computing their solutions. This is due in part to the wide range of abovementioned applications, which indeed has recently attracted much attention from the numerical PDE and scientific communities [7,22,26,31,65,66,68,71,84,87,83,85,86,96,137,133,142,147]. Significant progress has been made due to these collective efforts, but many issues still remain open. We believe that these advancements and new results are sufficient both in quality and in quantity to warrant a survey article on the subject, which should provide a timely and valuable contribution and service to the community. We hope that this article will generate more interest in numerical methods for fully nonlinear PDEs. We also hope that increasing awareness of this class of problems will bring fresh ideas and produce novel methods and algorithms for solving problems from one of the last frontiers in numerical PDEs. nonlinear second order PDEs over the last forty years. These are the classical and weak solution concepts and theories. We recall that a classical solution of a second order PDE must possess second order continuous derivatives and satisfy the given PDE at every point in the domain where the PDE is considered (and fulfills the prescribed boundary condition). Classical solution theory tackles issues such as the existence, uniqueness, and regularity of solutions. The uniqueness is often inferred by some comparison principle which in turn is a consequence of some maximum principle (e.g., the Hopf maximum principle or the Aleksandrov-Bakelman-Pucci maximum principle [93,105]). In order to guarantee a maximum principle, the underlying fully nonlinear differential operator must fulfill some kind of monotonicity property. Among the PDEs associated with such a fully nonlinear differential operator, the so-called elliptic are of particular interest. We recall that a fully nonlinear second order operator
div.formula: F : R d×d × R d × R × Ω → R is (degenerate) elliptic if F (A, p, z, x) ≤ F (B, p, z, x) for all x ∈ Ω, z ∈ R, p ∈ R d ,

div.head: and A, B ∈ R d×d
div.p: sym with A ≥ B [43,56]. 1 In addition, the operator F is proper if it is degenerate elliptic and satisfies F (A, p, u, x) ≤ F (A, p, v, x) whenever u ≤ v. For example, the Monge-Ampère equation det(D 2 u) = f is elliptic only for strictly convex function u (cf. [43,52,93,105]) (and if f > 0). Hence, the Monge-Ampère operator v →det(D 2 v) is not elliptic in full generality, but it is when restricted to the set of strictly convex functions. Notice that unless stated otherwise, Ω ⊂ R d is used to denote a bounded domain.

The existence of classical solutions is a more difficult issue for fully nonlinear second order elliptic PDEs compared to linear or mildly nonlinear problems. The most often used techniques for proving existence are the method of continuity and the fixed point theorem, which are based on topological arguments and require some crucial a priori estimates of the solutions. In the case of second order quasi-linear PDEs, the fixed point argument is carried out in the Hölder space C 1,α (0 < α < 1), so C 1,α a priori solution estimates must be obtained. However, in the case of second order fully nonlinear PDEs, due to the full nonlinearity, the method of continuity must be carried out in the Hölder space C 2,α . As a result, C 2,α a priori estimates need to be derived, which is a considerably more difficult task. It is now well known that for a large class of fully nonlinear second order PDEs, the required C 2,α a priori estimates are provided by the celebrated Evans-Krylov theorem, which was proved independently by L. C. Evans and N. Krylov in 1982 (cf. [75,120]; see also [40]). We also note that the celebrated De Giorgi-Nash Hölder estimate in the high-dimensional quasi-linear theory (cf. [93]) is substituted by the Krylov-Safonov Hölder estimate (cf. [43]) in the high-dimensional fully nonlinear theory. By the mid-1980s, the classical theory for fully nonlinear PDEs had been well developed (cf. [43] and [93,Chapter 17]).

It should be pointed out that the existence of classical solutions depends strongly on the regularity of both the data and the boundary ∂Ω as well as structure conditions on both the data and the domain. For example, the Dirichlet problem for the Monge-Ampère equation det(D 2 u) = f does not in general have a classical solution unless Ω is a uniformly convex domain in the sense that Ω = {x ∈ R d ; ϕ(x) < 0} for some ϕ ∈ C 2 such that D 2 ϕ ≥ λI d×d (λ > 0), where I d×d denotes the d × d identity matrix. The following are two illustrating examples: Geometrically, u is a viscosity solution if, for every C 2 function ϕ that "touches" the graph of u from above at x 0 , there holds F [ϕ](x 0 ) ≤ 0, and if ϕ "touches" the graph of u from below at x 0 , there holds F [ϕ](x 0 ) ≥ 0 (see Figure 1.1). We also remark that the above definition can be generalized to the case when both F and u are only bounded functions, which can be easily done using the lower and upper semicontinuous envelopes of F and u (cf. [12]).

A powerful tool in viscosity solution theory for second order fully nonlinear equations is the comparison principle. Generally speaking, the comparison principle asserts that if F is elliptic, u, v are, respectively, a viscosity subsolution and a viscosity supersolution to (1.1), i.e., if F [u] ≤ 0 and F [v] ≥ 0 and u ≤ v on ∂Ω, then u ≤ v in all of Ω. Clearly such a result leads to uniqueness of viscosity solutions, namely, if F [u] = F [v] in Ω (in the viscosity sense) and u = v on ∂Ω, then u = v. Indeed, if u, v ∈ A are two viscosity solutions of (1.1) with u = v on ∂Ω, then F [u] ≤ 0, F[v] ≥ 0, and u ≤ v, implying u ≤ v in Ω. Switching the roles of u and v we obtain u ≥ v and so u = v.

From the above viscosity solution definition, it is clear that the concept of viscosity solutions is nonvariational: no integration by parts is involved. Instead, the "hard-tocontrol" derivatives on the solution is thrown to a fixed test function at certain points via a maximum principle. Borrowing some terminology from [55,76], we shall refer to the weak solution concept and theory based on the maximum principles as "the differentiation by parts approach," which is significantly different from the integration by parts approach discussed earlier. As we shall see, this is the primary source of difficulties in developing reliable and efficient numerical methods and algorithms for computing viscosity solutions (see sections 2-4 for details).

div.head: Classification of Numerical Methods for PDEs.
div.p: Except in some very simple situations, closed form solutions do not exist even for linear PDEs, and therefore numerical techniques become the only viable way to find (and visualize) the solution(s) of a given PDE problem. The field of numerical PDEs is concerned with the design, analysis, and computer implementation of numerical methods and algorithms for solving PDE problems. This field has blossomed in the past forty years, and especially in the last twenty years. This phenomenal development has largely been driven by the ever increasing demands for the solution of important and complicated scientific, engineering, and industrial application problems such as flow and transport, weather prediction, wave propagation, composite and nano materials design and analysis, and genetic network identification and prediction. It has also been facilitated by the rapid advances in computer hardware and the emergence of parallel computing technology in recent years. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php Numerical discretization methods for PDEs are very diverse, and there are too many to enumerate. However, conceptually all the major methods can be roughly categorized into the following four classes: (1) Methods based on directly approximating derivatives by difference quotients; (2) methods based on variational principles and approximating infinite-dimensional spaces by finite-dimensional spaces; (3) methods based on finite basis expansions and approximating PDEs at sampling points; (4) none of the above. Obviously, the first class consists of finite differences methods. The second class consists of Galerkin-type methods such as finite element methods, least squares methods, spectral Galerkin methods, discontinuous Galerkin (DG) methods, finite volume methods, and boundary element methods. The third class consists of collocation methods and meshless methods. Finally, the fourth class mainly contains specialized methods, such as lattice Boltzmann methods, which are often designed for specialized PDEs and their applications. It also contains the composite methods that involve more than one type of discretization technique. We remark that, although there is no guarantee that any of the above methods listed in classes ( 1)-(3) will work, they can at least be formulated for linear and quasi-linear PDEs without too much difficulty. The methodologies for such methods for linear and quasi-linear PDEs have been well documented in the past forty years [33,48,53,128,138,156,157,159,170,179].

div.head: Challenges for Solving Fully Nonlinear Second Order PDEs.
div.p: To discretize a given fully nonlinear PDE, it is natural to first try to apply and adapt the successful discretization methods developed for linear and quasi-linear PDEs. Indeed, such a strategy works pretty well in the case of fully nonlinear first order PDEs; we refer the reader to [1,35,60,131,149,150,160,154,161,181,182] and the references therein for more details in this direction. On the other hand, the situation for fully nonlinear second order PDEs is strikingly different. None of the three classes of numerical PDE methods listed in section 1.3 works right away for fully nonlinear second order PDEs. In fact, the second class of methods cannot even be formulated because, in general, there is no variational principle to start with for fully nonlinear PDEs. For the first and third classes of methods, a naive application of those methods to fully nonlinear second order PDEs can lead to disastrous results.

To illustrate this last point, we solve the Monge-Ampère equation det(D2 u) = f in Ω = (0, 1) 2 using a finite difference method and chose the Dirichlet data g and the source function f such that the exact solution is u = e (x 2 1 +x 2 2 )/2 ∈ C ∞ (Ω). It follows from, e.g., [54], that the Dirichlet Monge-Ampère problem has at most two solutions. We discretize the PDE using the standard nine-point stencil and use Newton's method to solve the resulting nonlinear algebraic system. One would hope, as in the continuous case, there exist at most two discrete solutions. However, as shown by Figure 1.2 for a 4 × 4 grid, sixteen numerical solutions are obtained by varying the initial guess in the Newton method! 2 As this example demonstrates, an additional challenge in constructing usable discretization schemes is caused by the conditional uniqueness of fully nonlinear second order PDEs; that is, solutions are unique only when restricted to a certain function class. Nonuniqueness and conditional uniqueness of solutions are common for fully nonlinear second order PDEs; and Monge-Ampère-type equations are notorious in this regard. This presents a great challenge from a numerical viewpoint since a numerical method must be designed so that it has the ability to select the correct desired solution. In addition, no matter which discretization scheme is used, the resulting algebraic systems are expected to be highly nonlinear because of the full nonlinearity of the PDEs. Solving nonlinear systems is another primary numerical challenge associated with fully nonlinear second order PDEs. Newton's method is often the method of choice. However, providing a good initial guess for Newton's method can be as difficult as solving the nonlinear algebraic system itself. Finally, in addition to numerical experiment validation, in order to give a solid footing to any numerical method, convergence analysis and rates of convergence (if possible) of the numerical method are indispensable and critically important issues which need to be addressed. Such tasks have proved to be very difficult to accomplish and are often left untouched in the literature.

div.head: Outline of the Article. The remainder of the article is organized as follows.
div.p: In section 2, we provide a detailed survey of all the numerical methods (of which we are aware) for fully nonlinear second order PDEs with a particular emphasis on Monge-Ampère-type equations. We divide these methods into two groups depending on whether a method uses a finite difference discretization technique or a Galerkin discretization technique. Inside each group, the methods are further divided based on some main characteristics of the methods. Due to the authors' intensive experience with two types of methodologies, namely, augmented Lagrangian and least squares methods and the vanishing moment methodology and the concept of moment solutions, Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php these two types of methods are presented, respectively, in sections 3 and 4 in greater detail. Section 5 is devoted to describing various applications of fully nonlinear second order PDEs, which range from astrophysics, conformal geometry, grid generation, optimal transport, and image processing to semigeostrophic flow. In section 6, we conclude this article with a summary and some remarks.

div.head: Recent
div.p: Developments in Numerical Methods. In this section, we provide a summary of the recent advancements in numerical methods for fully nonlinear second order PDEs. We break the methods into two main groups: finite difference methods and Galerkin-type methods. Within each group, we divide and classify the methods further based upon their characteristics as well as the problems for which they are designed. Both advantages and disadvantages of some of the methods are discussed.

div.head: Finite Difference Methods.
div.p: 2.1.1. Geometric Methods. The first numerical method to compute the solution of a fully nonlinear second order PDE was introduced by Oliker and Prussner [148] in 1988 for the two-dimensional Monge-Ampère equation with Dirichlet boundary conditions. To explain their method and the motivation behind it, we must first give a geometric interpretation of the Monge-Ampère problem, that is, how the problem arises in the context of differential geometry [152,153]. In this direction, for a continuous function u
div.formula: : Ω → R, let ∂u(x 0 ) := {p ∈ R 2 : u(x) ≥ u(x 0 )+p•(x-x 0 ) ∀x ∈ Ω} denote the subdifferential (or normal mapping) of u and, for E ⊂ Ω, let ∂u(E) := ∪ x∈E ∂u(x).
div.p: Then the Monge-Ampère measure associated with u is defined as
div.formula: M u (E) := L 2 (∂u(E)) for any Borel set E ⊂ Ω,
div.p: where L 2 denotes the two-dimensional Lebesgue measure. 3 The Monge-Ampère problem is then defined as seeking a continuous convex function u with prescribed Dirichlet boundary data u = g on ∂Ω such that

for some given Radon measure μ. A function u satisfying (2.1) and (2.2b) is said to be an Aleksandrov solution to the Monge-Ampère equation (2.2). 4 Note that if u ∈ C 1 (Ω) and is strictly convex, then ∂u(x 0 ) = ∇u(x 0 ). Moreover, if u ∈ C 2 (Ω), then by a simple change of variables along with Sard's theorem [105,135] we have 2 for any Borel set E ⊂ Ω.
div.formula: M u (E) = ∇u(E) dL 2 = E det(D 2 u) dL
div.p: Thus, if μ is absolutely continuous with respect to Lebesgue measure with μ(E)
div.formula: = E f dL 2 , then u satisfies det(D 2 u) = f in Ω ⊂ R 2 , (2.2a) u = g on ∂Ω. (2.2b)
div.p: Instead of the onerous task of discretizing the PDE (2.2) directly, Oliker and Prussner discretized its geometric interpretation (2.1). As a first step, they approximated the measure μ by Dirac measures {μ i } N i=1 concentrated at a finite number of points inside Ω. In particular, they partitioned the domain Ω into N disjoint open subdomains {Ω i } N i=1 , with Ω = ∪ N i=1 Ω i , chose a single arbitrary point a i ∈ Ω i , and set
div.formula: μ i = Ωi f dL 2 .
div.p: The discrete analogue of (2.1) is then to find a piecewise linear, continuous, and convex function u N that takes the linear interpolant of g on the boundary such that
div.formula: M uN (a i ) = μ i . (2.3) Note that (2.3) implies M uN (E) =
div.p: ai∈E a i , and therefore, under certain mild conditions, this process produces a sequence {u N } N converging to some convex u with M uN → M u weakly as L 2 (Ω i ) → 0. As a result, u is the solution to (2.1) and (2.2b), that is, u is an Aleksandrov solution to the Monge-Ampère equation (2.2). Since problem (2.3) is defined in a finite-dimensional setting, the left-hand side of (2.3) can be computed explicitly using standard difference quotients leading to a nonlinear algebraic problem. In order to solve the resulting system, Oliker and Prussner proposed and implemented an iterative sweeping procedure that produces a sequence {u
div.formula: (i) N } i that converges linearly in C(Ω) to the solution u N , i.e., u (i) N -u N L ∞ (Ω) ≤ τ u (i-1) N -u N L ∞ (Ω)
div.p: for some τ ∈ (0, 1). In addition, a Newton method is implemented once the computed solution is close to the true solution in order to speed up convergence.

Since the numerical method is based on the geometric interpretation of the Monge-Ampère equation, the scheme is very robust, being able to compute very singular solutions. Moreover, no special information about an initial guess is required to ensure convergence. That being said, there are some drawbacks of this particular method. The most obvious one is that it is problem specific; the method is designed solely for the two-dimensional Monge-Ampère equation, and therefore is difficult to generalize to other fully nonlinear PDEs that do not have geometric interpretations. Furthermore, the iterative procedure converges only linearly and therefore requires many sweeps to obtain a reasonable solution, making the efficiency of the scheme less than desirable. Finally, we mention that a detailed convergence analysis, (e.g., determining the rate of convergence of the error uu N ) remains an open problem. Still, this method opened the door to numerical methods for the Monge-Ampère equation and motivated the numerical community to develop faster and more general methods.

div.head: Monotone Finite Difference Methods of Kuo and Trudinger.
div.p: The first type of monotone scheme that we discuss is that of finite difference methods of positive type introduced by Kuo and Trudinger in [124]. This type of methods is an extension of the schemes of the same name introduced in [139] for linear elliptic problems, and they share similar characteristics such as the discrete maximum principle. To describe and motivate these methods, we first recall that if a nonlinear second order differential operator F [u](x) = F (D 2 u(x), ∇u(x), u(x), x) is differentiable, then it is elliptic at û if its linearization at û is elliptic as a linear PDE. In particular, if we denote points in R d×d × R d × R × Ω by (r, p, z, x) and use their subscripts to denote partial differentiation, then F is elliptic at û if there exist positive constants λ, Λ such that
div.formula: λI d×d ≤ F r [û] ≤ ΛI d×d . (2.4a)
div.p: where μ 1 , μ 0 , μ are fixed positive constants. Kuo and Trudinger's finite difference schemes mimic the structure of F and have the general form
div.formula: F h [u] = F (δ 2 u, δu, u, x) = 0, (2.5) where δu = {δ y u : y ∈ Y }, δ 2 u = {δ 2 y u : y ∈ Y }, δ y u(x) = 1 2|y| u(x + y) -u(x -y) , and δ 2 y u(x) = 1 |y| 2 u(x + y) -2u(x) + u(x -y) .
div.p: Here, Y denotes the available (nontrivial) directions on the finite difference grid up to some prescribed length N .
div.formula: Denoting points in R Y × R Y × R × Ω by (s, q, z, x), a scheme F h is of positive type if 5 ∂F ∂s y - |y| 2 ∂F ∂q y ≥ 0, (2.6a) ∂F ∂z ≤ 0 (2.6b)
div.p: for all y = he i , i = 1, 2, . . . , d, and some positive constant h, where {e i } d i=1 denotes the canonical basis of R d . As explained in [124], a consistent difference scheme of positive type can be constructed for any operator satisfying the structure conditions (2.4) by taking N large enough; that is, by increasing the number of directions on the finite difference grid. Moreover, schemes can be constructed with stronger monotonicity conditions with 0 replaced by λ 0 in (2.6a) and 0 replaced by c 0 in (2.6b) for some positive constants λ 0 , c 0 . The authors provided a couple of arguments to prove that there exists a unique solution to (2.5), one of which is a fixed point argument based on the Brouwer fixed point theorem and a priori estimates of the numerical solutions. The other argument is an iterative method which mimics the method of continuity. In addition to proving the existence of a solution to (2.5), this iterative procedure provides a practical way to compute the solution. As a byproduct of their convergence analysis, Kuo and Trudinger also deduced the existence of a Hölder continuous solution to (1.1) under the structure conditions (2.4). To the best of our knowledge, the practical implementation of these finite difference methods have not yet been investigated.

div.head: The Framework of Barles-Souganidis and Extensions.
div.p: In [12], Barles and Souganidis developed a general framework to study approximation schemes (not necessarily discrete) for general fully nonlinear elliptic and parabolic second order PDEs. Below we describe the main results of [12] for elliptic PDEs and refer the reader to the paper for a detailed exposition of the parabolic PDEs.
Again, assume
div.formula: F [u](x) = F (D 2 u(x), ∇u(x), u(x), x
div.p: ) is an elliptic operator (see Definition 1.1) and is defined on Ω. Let B(Ω) denote the set of all bounded functions on Ω, and let S : R + × Ω × R × B(Ω) → R be an operator that satisfies the following three conditions:
div.formula: (i) Monotonicity. S(ρ, x, t, u) ≤ S(ρ, x, t, v) if u ≥ v for all ρ ≥ 0, x ∈ Ω, t ∈ R, and u, v ∈ B(Ω).
div.p: (ii) Solvability and Stability. For all ρ > 0, there exists a solution u ρ ∈ B(Ω) to the following problem:
(2.7) S(ρ, x, u ρ (x), u ρ ) = 0 in Ω.
Moreover, there exists a ρ-independent constant C > 0 such that
div.formula: u ρ L ∞ (Ω) ≤ C.
div.p: (iii) Consistency. For all x ∈ Ω and φ ∈ C ∞ (Ω) there hold lim sup
div.formula: ρ→0 y→x ξ→0 S(ρ, y, φ(y) + ξ, φ + ξ) ρ ≤ F (D 2 φ(x), ∇φ(x), φ(x), x), lim inf ρ→0 y→x ξ→0 S(ρ, y, φ(y) + ξ, φ + ξ) ρ ≥ F (D 2 φ(x), ∇φ(x), φ(x), x).
div.p: We remark that the assumption that F [u](x) is defined on Ω instead of Ω is a shorthand notation used in [12] to write both the PDE and the boundary condition as one expression. The reason that the right-hand side of the two inequalities in (iii) above are the same is that we have assumed F is continuous in all of its arguments (see Definition 1.1). If the continuity assumption is dropped, then F in the first and second inequalities has to be replaced by its upper and and lower semicontinuous envelopes F * and F * , respectively.

One of the main results of [12] is the following convergence theorem. Theorem 2.1 (cf. Theorem 2.1 of [12]). Suppose that the elliptic problem F [u](x) = 0 in Ω satisfies the comparison principle (hence, it has a unique viscosity solution u ∈ C 0 (Ω)). Assume that the (approximation) operator S satisfies conditions (i)-(iii) above. Then the solution u ρ of (2.7) converges locally uniformly to the unique viscosity of F [u](x) = 0 in Ω.

Clearly, the above result provides a guideline (i.e., a set of sufficient conditions) for constructing convergent approximation schemes, although it does not say how to construct such schemes (i.e., how to construct the approximation operator S). In this direction, we mention two finite difference schemes which fall into the framework of Barles and Souganidis. The first one is a monotone finite difference method recently proposed by Caffarelli and Souganidis in [47], for which they were also able to establish a convergence rate (in the maximum norm) of order O(h α ) for some α > 0. The practical implementation of this finite difference method has not yet been investigated.

In [146], Oberman introduced a class of monotone finite difference schemes called degenerate elliptic schemes. These finite difference methods are represented at each grid point by an expression of the form
div.formula: F (i) h [u] = F (i) h u i , u i -u j ; j ∈ N (i) =: F (i) h (u i , u i -u j ), (2.8)
div.p: where N (i) denotes the list of the indices of those mesh points that are neighbors of x i , and u j is shorthand for the set {u j } j∈N (i) . A scheme F h is then defined to be degenerate elliptic if each component
div.formula: F (i) h
div.p: is nondecreasing in each variable. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php Similar to finite difference methods of positive type, the definition and construction of degenerate elliptic schemes are motivated by the definition and properties of viscosity solutions. In particular, it was shown in [146] that if F h is a degenerate elliptic finite difference scheme, then a discrete version of the comparison principle holds. Namely, if
div.formula: F h [u] ≤ F h [v]
div.p: , then u ≤ v at all mesh points. As a byproduct of this result, the uniqueness of solutions easily follows. To prove existence of the scheme, Oberman constructed the explicit Euler map S ρ [u] = u -ρF h [u] and showed that the mapping is a contraction provided F is a Lipschitz continuous degenerate elliptic scheme and ρ is taken small enough (specifically, if ρ is taken less than the inverse of the Lipschitz constant of F h ). This result also suggests a practical iterative solution procedure to compute solutions of the schemes, although this procedure can be computationally expensive if F h has a large Lipschitz constant.

div.head: Finite Difference Schemes for Bellman-Type Equations.
div.p: Recall that the (time-independent) Bellman equation reads
div.formula: sup ν∈V L ν u -f ν = 0. (2.9)
div.p: Here, {L ν } ν is a family of possibly degenerate second order linear equations, and V is a set of admissible controls. Problem (2.9) arises from the dynamic programming principle for a controlled Markov diffusion process, u being the value function (see section 5.10 for more details). Unlike other fully nonlinear second order PDEs (such as Monge-Ampère-type PDEs), there is a large amount of literature on numerical methods (mainly of the finite difference type), going back nearly forty years, for the approximate solution of Bellman-type equations. The reasons for these successful analytical and numerical developments are due to (i) the linear structure appearing in (2.9) and (ii) its probabilistic interpretation. Because of the vast literature on numerical methods for Bellman-type equations, and due to page limitations, we can only give a brief and somewhat incomplete review of the subject. We refer the reader to [88,127,126,125] and references therein for a detailed account of numerical methods for these problems as well as their implementation.

As previously stated, all numerical methods for Bellman equations in the literature are finite difference approximations. Broadly speaking, there are two approaches to constructing and analyzing difference schemes for the Bellman equation: probabilistic methods and viscosity solution methods. In the first case, a controlled Markov diffusion process is approximated by a controlled Markov chain on a lattice with nearest neighbor transitions. The dynamic programming equation then leads to a discretized Bellman equation, where the first and second order partial derivatives in (2.9) are replaced by appropriate finite difference quotients. It should be noted that in using this methodology, one automatically ends up with monotone finite difference schemes [88]. The proof of convergence of these methods then reduces to showing that the chains converge (weakly) to the underlying controlled diffusion process. As pointed out in [122], this is not an easy task, as the set of weak limit points of the controlled Markov chains can be larger than the set of processes that can be obtained by controlling the diffusion process. Therefore, when proving convergence, some tricks need to be employed. In contrast, the viscosity solution approach does not assume an underlying Markov chain approximation, but rather only assumes that the difference schemes are consistent, stable, and monotone. As such, they are more general than the probabilistic methods, although the construction of such general schemes is less clear. Under the viscosity solution framework, the convergence theory of such schemes is much simpler due to the abstract theory of Barles and Souganidis [12]. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php Although numerical methods have been around for quite some time, rates of convergence of these difference schemes have only recently been obtained. The breakthrough occurred in [121,122], where Krylov obtained rates of convergence by combining both analytic (PDE) and probabilistic methods. Combining the novel technique called "shaking the coefficients" with a mollification argument, Krylov obtained smooth subsolutions of the PDE (2.9). With such subsolutions, he was then able to find a one-sided bound for the error. To obtain a one-sided bound in the opposite direction, Krylov used some probabilistic arguments. These results were later improved and generalized by several authors in [9,10,11,24,113,123].

div.head: Wide-Stencil Finite Difference Schemes.
div.p: As is now well known [139], even for linear elliptic equations, it is generally not possible to build monotone finite difference schemes using a narrow stencil. Therefore, in light of the framework set by Barles and Souganidis [12], wide-stencil schemes seem to be the most feasible option to solve fully nonlinear second order PDEs using finite difference methods. In this direction, Oberman [147] constructed some wide-stencil finite difference schemes for fully nonlinear PDEs which can be written as functions of the eigenvalues of the Hessian matrix in two dimensions, i.e., problem (1.1) takes the form

where λ -[u] (resp., λ + [u]) represents the smallest (resp., largest) eigenvalue of the Hessian matrix D 2 u. Examples of problems such as (2.10) include the Monge-Ampère equation G(λ -, λ + ) = λ -λ + , Pucci's equation G(λ -, λ + ) = αλ + + λ -, and the equation for the convex envelope G(λ -, λ + ) = λ -.

Oberman's methods are based on the classical Rayleigh-Ritz characterization of the eigenvalues, i.e., (2.11) where v θ = (cos θ, sin θ) is the unit vector in the direction of the angle θ. The schemes in [147] were based on the simple idea of replacing the characterization of the eigenvalues (2.11) by the standard centered difference approximation
div.formula: λ -[u](x) = min θ∈[0,2π] d 2 u dv 2 θ (x), λ + [u](x) = max θ∈[0,2π] d 2 u ∂v 2 θ (x),
λ - h,dθ [u](x) = min i u(x + v i ) -2u(x) + u(x -v i ) |v i | 2 , (2.12a) λ + h,dθ [u](x) = max i u(x + v i ) -2u(x) + u(x -v i ) |v i | 2 . (2.12b)
div.p: Here, the v i 's are the directions that are available on the computational grid (see Figure 2.1); they are determined by the spatial resolution h and the directional resolution dθ. Note that the spatial resolution h is improved by introducing more grid points (i.e., refining the grid), while the directional resolution dθ is improved by increasing the width of the stencil.
Replacing the eigenvalues with the discrete versions (2.12) yields the following scheme for (2.10):
Oberman proved that the finite difference scheme (2.13) satisfies the convergence criterion set by Barles and Souganidis [12] [147].

and therefore the method converges to the unique viscosity solution of the underlying PDE problem as h and dθ tend to zero. However, no rate of convergence was given even for classical solutions. To solve the nonlinear algebraic problem F h,dθ [u] = 0, Oberman proposed the iterative method u n+1 = u n + ρF h,dθ [u n ]. Similar to the Euler map introduced for degenerate elliptic schemes described in section 2.1.3, this iterative procedure was shown to converge if a certain CFL (Courant-Friedrichs-Lewy) condition, which depends upon the Lipschitz constant of F h,dθ , is respected (e.g., ρ ≤ h 2 ).

Improving on these results in the case of the Monge-Ampère equation (2.2), Oberman and Froese recently extended the wide-stencil finite difference schemes to any dimension [92,91]. There are two main principles behind extending the work of [147] to the higher-dimensional case. First, in order to compute the (correct) convex solution of the Monge-Ampère equation, they imposed the convexity criterion on the PDE by considering the equivalent problem det + (D 2 u) = f, where det + (D 2 u) = d j=1 max{λ j [u], 0}. Second, to generalize the wide-stencil finite difference schemes to the higher-dimensional case, instead of using the Rayleigh-Ritz characterization (2.11), the authors used a variational characterization of the modified determinant
div.formula: det + (D 2 u) = min (ν1,...,ν d )∈V d j=1 max ∂ 2 u ∂ν 2 j , 0 . (2.14)
div.p: Here, V denotes the set of all orthonormal bases of R d . Similar to the two-dimensional case, the authors replace the complete set of orthonormal vectors {ν j } d j=1 in their numerical schemes by a subset which is determined by the computational grid and stencil. As in [147], they showed that their methods are consistent, stable, and monotone, and thus converge to the unique convex viscosity solution of the underlying PDE problem as the discretization parameter and directional resolution parameter tend to zero. To solve the underlying nonlinear algebraic system, the authors used Newton's method, which was shown to converge if a good initial guess is provided. Several twoand three-dimensional examples were provided, that showed the robustness of their methods and indicated that the CPU time used is much less than for the iterative method used in [147].

As expected, these wide-stencil finite difference methods have both advantages and disadvantages. Due to the convergence criterion set by Barles and Souganidis [12], the convergence analysis reduces to showing that the methods are consistent Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php and monotone. Thus, once such schemes are constructed, their convergence analysis becomes trivial. Furthermore, due to this general framework and theory, the methods proposed are robust for a variety of challenging problems. On the other hand, they have some (inherited) disadvantages as well. First, due to their design, it is not clear (or at least very difficult) how to generalize them to other fully nonlinear PDEs that cannot be written in the form (2.10) or (2.14). Second, these methods produce two different sources of error: the spatial resolution h and the directional resolution dθ. Therefore, in order to obtain highly accurate numerical solutions, not only does one have to refine the grid, one must at the same time increase the size of the stencil, which can be very impractical. The numerical experiment results reported in [147,92,91] seem to confirm this observation.

We remark that, in order to overcome the above-mentioned disadvantages of the wide-stencil finite difference methods, very recently Feng, Kao, and Lewis [80] proposed a new and different (from the framework of Barles and Souganidis [12]) framework for constructing practical finite difference methods for fully nonlinear second order PDEs (including the Monge-Ampère equation). The proposed new framework is a natural extension of the well-known finite difference framework for the first order fully nonlinear Hamilton-Jacobi equations (cf. [59,17,117,162]), and the key concepts of the numerical Hamiltonian and numerical viscosity for the first order equations are replaced by the new concepts of numerical operator, generalized monotonicity, and numerical moment (the last one being inspired by the vanishing moment method; see section 4) for the second order equations in [80].

2.1.6. Some Other Finite Difference Schemes. Baginski and Whitaker [8] proposed a finite difference method to compute surfaces embedded in R 3 with constant Gaussian curvature K > 0 with prescribed boundary data. In [8], the authors considered the case in which the surface is given as the graph of a scalar function u. This then leads to the following Monge-Ampère-type problem called the equation of prescribed Gauss curvature:

To each boundary value problem (2.15) there corresponds a one-parameter family of surfaces with constant Gaussian curvature: (K, u, g) for K ∈ (0, K max ), where K max (which depends on both g and Ω) denotes the largest Gaussian curvature for which the surfaces exist (see section 5.2 for more details). In general, there are no theoretical estimates on K max , which motivates the need for numerical methods to solve (2.15). The design and implementation of Baginski and Whitaker's method parallel the analytic technique used to prove the solvability of (2.15). In particular, the proposed scheme was motivated by the method of continuity, which, as mentioned in section 1.2, is a standard technique to prove the existence of classical solutions for fully nonlinear equations. In the case of the prescribed Gauss curvature equation (2.15), the method of continuity considers a one-parameter family of solutions {u (t) } satisfying the Dirichlet boundary condition (2.15b) and
In a similar manner, Baginski and Whitaker proposed a discrete version of (2.16) using a nine-point stencil finite difference scheme, namely,
div.formula: det(D 2 h u (t) h ) = tK 1 + |D h u (t) h | 2 2 + (1 -t) det(D 2 h u (0) h ) (2.
div.p: The desired solution then corresponds to t n = 1. The authors used a discrete subsolution as an initial guess and a modified Newton method at each t-value to compute the nonlinear system resulting from (2.17). A continuation method was also employed to numerically determine an approximation for K max . No convergence results were provided, but several two-dimensional numerical experiments were described.

Loeper and Rapetti [133] considered the problem of finding a periodic function u such that u + |x| 2 /2 is convex and a solution of the shifted Monge-Ampère equation det(I d×d + D 2 u) = f (with periodic boundary conditions). To solve this problem, they introduced the following (nondiscrete) Newton iteration:
Given u 0 , for n = 1, 2, . . . ,
div.formula: (i) compute f n = det(I d×d + D 2 u n ); (ii) assemble cof(I d×d + D 2 u n ), the cofactor matrix of I d×d + D 2 u n ;
div.p: (iii) compute the solution of the linearized Monge-Ampère equation
div.formula: cof(I d×d + D 2 u n ) : D 2 θ n = 1 τ (f -f n ); (2.18) (iv) update iteration, u n+1 = u n + θ n .
div.p: Here, A : B denotes the Frobenius inner product between matrices A and B, i.e., A : B = i,j A ij B ij . Loeper and Rapetti proved that if f ∈ C α (Ω) and the damping parameter τ is taken large enough, the above algorithm converges in C 2,α (Ω) to the (unique up to a constant) solution u for every 0 < α < α. The strategy of their proof is to first show that the sequence {f n } converges monotonically to f in C α (Ω) using an induction argument. With this fact established, the authors resort to some a priori estimates due to Caffarelli [41] and then employ the Arzelà-Ascoli theorem to conclude that the sequence {u n } is precompact in C 2,α (Ω). From this result, it follows that the whole sequence must converge to the solution of the periodic Monge-Ampère equation. Based upon the above nondiscrete algorithm, Loeper and Rapetti proposed a discrete version using a second order centered finite difference scheme to assemble the two matrices D 2 u n and cof(I d×d +D 2 u n ) and used a BiCG (bi-conjugate gradient) method to solve (2.18). Although no convergence analysis was provided for the discrete algorithm, the authors demonstrated that the iterative method converges if a good initial guess is provided.

In [22], Benamou, Froese, and Oberman proposed a simple finite difference method for the two-dimensional Monge-Ampère equation (2.2) based on the standard ninepoint stencil on a uniform Cartesian grid. In particular, the authors discretized the Monge-Ampère equation as
div.formula: D 2 xx u ij D 2 yy u ij -D 2 xy u ij = f i,j , (2.19)
div.p: where 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php and u i,j is an approximation to u(ih, jh). Introducing the notation
div.formula: D 2 xx u ij = 1 h 2 u i+1,j -2u i,j + u i-1,j , D 2 yy u ij = 1 h 2 u i,j+1 -2u i,j + u i,j-1 , D 2 xy u ij = 1 4h 2 u i+1,j+1 + u i-1,j-1 -u i-1,j+1 -u i+1,j-1 , f i,j = f (ih, jh), Downloaded 05/21/13 to
div.p: the discretization (2.19) can then be written compactly as
Solving for u i,j yields the identity

Equation (2.21) indicates that at each interior grid point there exist up to two solutions, which explains the numerical results presented in section 1.4. In [22], the authors simply chose the smaller root in (2.21). The motivation in doing so is the convex criterion of the Monge-Ampère equation. Indeed, it is an easy exercise to show that the solution satisfies the following directional convexity along all grid directions τ :
div.formula: u(x) ≤ u(x + τ ) + u(x -τ ) 2 .
div.p: Since it can be shown that the numerical scheme (2.21) is both consistent and stable, it suffices to show that the method is monotone in order to prove that the solution converges to the viscosity solution of the underlying PDE problem. This monotonicity property will hold if, for example, the value u i,j is a nondecreasing function of its neighboring values. However, as emphasized in [22], this is not the case for the numerical scheme (2.20). As a result, the scheme is not monotone and, hence, a proof of convergence of this simple finite difference scheme remains an open problem.
Galerkin-Type Methods.

div.head: L 2 Projection Methods.
div.p: In [26], Böhmer introduced an L 2 projection method to approximate classical solutions of general fully nonlinear second elliptic equations. The design of such methods is actually quite simple and intuitive. The motivation of the method comes from the fact that if u is a smooth (i.e., classical) solution to (1.1), then for all smooth test functions v there holds

Note that this is also the starting point for finite element methods for linear, semilinear, and quasi-linear PDEs. The key difference is that in the fully nonlinear case we cannot throw the "hard-to-control" derivatives onto the test function using integration by parts to obtain a variational formulation in a weaker Sobolev space. The L 2 projection method of (1.1) is based upon posing (2.22) in a finite-dimensional setting, using piecewise polynomials as trial and test functions (i.e., finite element functions). In particular, the method is defined as seeking a function u h ∈ V h with prescribed Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php
div.formula: F [u] = 0 discretize -→ F h [u h ] = 0 ⏐ ⏐ linearize ⏐ ⏐ linearize L u (w) = 0 discretize -→ L u,h (w h ) = 0 Fig. 2.2
div.p: An abstract commuting diagram used to derive convergent finite element methods in [31,32,140]. In the case of the Monge-Ampère equation, we have
div.formula: F [u] = f - det(D 2 u) and Lu(w) = -∇ • (cof(D 2 u)∇w), where cof(D 2 u) denotes the cofactor matrix of D 2 u.
div.p: Dirichlet boundary data such that
div.formula: Ω F (D 2 u h , ∇u h , u h , x)v h dx = 0 ∀v h ∈ V h ∩ H 1 0 (Ω). (2.23)
div.p: Note that for the relation (2.23) to make sense, the second order derivatives of u h have to be globally defined and bounded. As such, the use of C 1 finite element spaces (i.e., V h ⊂ C 1 ) is required. In [26], Böhmer considered two cases in parallel: the case where Ω is a convex, polyhedral domain, and the case where ∂Ω ∈ C 2 . In both cases it was shown, using intricate consistency and stability arguments, that there exists a unique solution to (2.23) provided that (i) F has an isolated solution u, and (ii) the Gâteaux derivative of F is invertible and bounded at u. In the case where Ω is a polyhedral domain, optimal order error estimates were also derived provided u is sufficiently smooth. In the second case, that is, ∂Ω ∈ C 2 , due to the variational crimes (i.e., approximation of the boundary), the order of convergence is reduced to at most two.

Recently, Brenner et al. expanded on these results by proposing and studying an L 2 projection method using C 0 finite element methods as well as discontinuous Galerkin (DG) methods for the Monge-Ampère equation (2.2) [31,32,140]. As explained in these papers, the guiding principle to deriving convergent finite element methods is to produce schemes such that the discrete linearization (at u) is consistent with the linear and elliptic PDE L u (w) := -∇ • cof(D 2 u)∇(w) , i.e., the linearization of the nonlinear PDE (2.2a). Here, cof(D 2 u) denotes the cofactor matrix of the Hessian D 2 u. In other words, it is desirable that the diagram in Figure 2.2 commutes. Note that for C 1 elements, the L 2 projection methods already inherit this commuting property. However, for finite element spaces with less regularity, the resulting methods are less intuitive. For example, the most natural C 0 method for the Monge-Ampère equation
div.formula: (2.2) is to find a function u h ∈ V h such that T ∈T h T f -det(D 2 u h ) v h dx = 0 ∀v h ∈ V h ∩ H 1 0 (Ω), (2.24)
div.p: where T h denotes the set of simplexes in the mesh. However, as emphasized in [31], even for smooth solutions, such methods do not work in practice (or analysis) due to the fact that the linearization of (2.24) is not stable (attributed to the fact that it is not consistent with the linearization L u ). To produce convergent schemes, Brenner et al. first considered finite element discretizations for the linear operator L u Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php denoted by L u,h . With this in hand, they then "delinearize," to obtain finite element approximations of the Monge-Ampère equation.
We illustrate this idea with an example using C 0 finite elements. 6 In this case, the discretization of the linear operator L u is defined as
div.formula: L u,h (w h ), v h = Ω cof(D 2 u)∇w h • ∇v h dx.
div.p: Integrating by parts and using the divergence-free row property of cofactor matrices [76], we obtain
div.formula: L u,h (w h ), v h = - T ∈T h T cof(D 2 u) : D 2 w h v h dx + e∈E i h e cof(D 2 u) ∇w h • n e v h ds,
div.p: where E i h denotes the set of interior edges in the mesh, w denotes the "jump" of a function w, and B denotes the "average" of a matrix-valued function B. Based upon this last identity, we can then "delinearize" to define the discretization of the Monge-Ampère equation as follows:
div.formula: F h [u h ], v h = T ∈T h T f -det(D 2 u h ) v h dx + e∈E i h e cof(D 2 u h ) ∇u h • n e v h ds.
div.p: In addition to deriving new L 2 projection-type methods, Brenner et al. [31,32] showed that the convergence analysis and error estimates of the nonlinear scheme reduce to the convergence analysis and error estimates of an auxiliary linear problem. As such, the authors were able to obtain quasi-optimal energy norm error estimates and L 2 error estimates.

One of the advantages of the L 2 projection methods is that they can handle curved boundaries and complicated geometries easily in comparison to finite difference methods. Furthermore, due to their polynomial degree flexibility, they have the ability to achieve greater accuracy if the exact solution is sufficiently smooth. That being said, the L 2 projection methods discussed here can be formulated and analyzed only in the case of classical solutions. Although numerical experiments [31] indicate that these methods are convergent for solutions as weak as H 2 (Ω), viscosity solutions in general do not inherit such regularity, and, therefore, the methods fail to converge in the most general setting. Furthermore, there is no uniqueness for the numerical solutions. Therefore, in order to compute the "correct" convex solution of the Monge-Ampère equation, a sufficiently good initial guess has to be given in Newton's method, and such a guess is in general difficult to find.

div.head: Other Galerkin Methods.
div.p: Another Galerkin method we discuss in this section is due to Benamou, Froese, and Oberman in [22], where the authors proposed an iterative method that only requires the solution of a sequence of Poisson equations for the two-dimensional Monge-Ampère equation. Their method is based on the fact that if u is the convex solution to the Monge-Ampère equation (2.2) and if u is sufficiently smooth (e.g., u ∈ H 2 (Ω)), then u is a fixed point of the operator T defined by
div.formula: T [v] = Δ -1 Δv 2 + 2 f -det(D 2 v) ,
div.p: where Δ -1 denotes the inverse operator of the Laplacian. Indeed, if u solves the PDE (2.2a) and is convex (so that Δu ≥ 0), then
div.formula: T [u] = Δ -1 Δu 2 = Δ -1 |Δu| = u.
div.p: Based on this fact, the authors proposed the following iterative strategy in order to obtain a fixed point of T :
div.formula: Δu n+1 = Δu n 2 + 2 f -det(D 2 u n ) in Ω, (2.25a) u n+1 = g on ∂Ω (2.25b)
div.p: for n = 0, 1, . . . . Although no convergence analysis was given for the iteration scheme (2.25), detailed numerical experiments were provided for a variety of problems. For smooth or mildly singular test problems, the method requires a relatively low number of iterations to converge. However, for singular test problems, that is, problems in which the solution is not in H 2 (Ω), the method may require thousands of iterations to converge.

To the best of our knowledge, there are very few works on Galerkin-type methods for Bellman equations in the literature. In [114], Jensen and Smears proposed and analyzed a monotone continuous linear finite element method on unstructured meshes. In [81], Feng and Lewis proposed and analyzed some mixed interior penalty discontinuous Galerkin (IP-DG) methods and local discontinuous Galerkin (LDG) methods for both elliptic and parabolic fully nonlinear PDEs (including Bellman equations) in the case of one spatial dimension. It is interesting to note that the DG methods of [81] are closely related to the finite difference methods proposed in [80] and the LDG methods of [81] are in a similar spirit to that of [178], where LDG methods were developed for first order Hamilton-Jacobi equations.

To conclude this section, we note that two other types of methods can also be included in the category of Galerkin methods, namely, augmented Lagrangian and least squares methods [64,65,66,67,68] and the vanishing moment method (combined with finite element methods) [84,85,86,87,83,142,82]. Because the authors of this paper have extensive experience on these two types of methodologies, those methods will be presented separately with greater detail in the subsequent two sections.

div.p: A typical choice for ρ is ρ = r (not optimal, but nearly optimal in many situations). The augmented Lagrangian methodology described above is really the basic one; it can be generalized to handle inequality constraints and use variable parameters r and ρ. We refer the reader to [89,97,143] for a detailed discussion of the augmented Lagrangian method and its multiple variants and various improvements.

div.head: Augmented Lagrangian Method for Monge-Amp ère-Type Equations.
div.p: To apply the augmented Lagrangian method to a fully nonlinear problem such as (2.2), we first need to formulate it as a constrained minimization problem. Actually, there are some commonalities between (2.2) and nonlinear variational problems from incompressible finite elasticity in the sense that they all involve functional determinants. The following is a typical example of such nonlinear variational problems:
div.formula: u = argmin v∈E Ω F (∇v, v, x) dx (3.5)
div.p: with Ω ⊂ R d (d = 2 or 3), the set E (of admissible displacements) being defined by
div.formula: E = v ∈ H 1 (Ω) d , v ∂Ω = u B , det(I d×d + ∇v) = 1 . (3.6)
div.p: Considering the fact that augmented Lagrangian based methods were successful at solving problem (3.5)-(3.6) (see [89,97,158] and the references therein for details), it was natural to attempt to solve (2.2) using a similar methodology. Following [64,67], we present one version of such an approach. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Assume also that (2.2) has a unique convex solution in H 2 (Ω). It is easy to verify the equivalence between (2.2) and the following minimization problem: Find (u, p) ∈ S such that j(u, p) ≤ j(v, q) ∀{v, q} ∈ S, where (3.7a)
Comparing (3.7) with (3.1), the linear constraint D 2 v -q = 0 will play the role of Bv = 0.
Following [89,97] (and [64,67]), we associate (3.7) with the following saddle point problem (with r > 0):

div.p: and λ n+1 ∈ Q as follows:

div.p: Algorithm (3.9) may seem a bit abstract. However, it follows from [65,67,68] that (3.9b)-(3.9c) can be reformulated as 11) is a well-posed linear variational problem of the biharmonic type; a detailed discussion of its iterative solution and mixed finite element approximation can be found in [67] (see also [68]). Concerning the iterative solution of problem (3.11), one can use a conjugate gradient algorithm operating in the spaces V g and V 0 equipped with the scalar product (v, w) → Ω ΔvΔw dx and the associated norm. As shown in [67,68], the discrete analogue of this algorithm requires the solution of two discrete Poisson problems per iteration, which makes its computer implementation rather simple.
div.formula: p n = argmin q∈Q + f 1 2 Ω |q| 2 dx - Ω D 2 u n-1 + 1 r λ n : q dx , (3.10) Ω Δu n Δv dx + r Ω D 2 u n : D 2 v dx = Ω rp n -λ n : D 2 v dx ∀v ∈ V 0 , (3.11) where u n ∈ V g and V 0 := H 2 (Ω) ∩ H 1 0 (Ω).
div.p: The minimization problem (3.10) can be solved pointwise; indeed, one has to solve for almost every x in Ω (in practice, for the interior vertices of a finite element triangulation of Ω) a tridimensional minimization problem of the following type:

To transform the three-dimensional constrained minimization problem (3.12) into an unconstrained two-dimensional one, we perform the change of variables z 1 = f (x)e ρ cosh θ, z 2 = f (x)e -ρ cosh θ, and z 3 = f (x) sinh θ. There is then equivalence between the minimization problem (3.12) and the following problem: Find
div.formula: (ρ n , θ n ) ∈ R 2 such that j n (ρ n , θ n ) ≤ j n (ρ, θ) for all (ρ, θ) ∈ R 2 , where j n (ρ, θ) = f (x) 2 cosh 2ρ cosh 2θ + cosh 2ρ + cosh 2θ -1 (3.15) -b n 1 (x)e ρ + b n 2 (x)e -ρ cosh θ -2b n 3 (x) sinh θ.
div.p: This in turn leads to the solution of
where Dj n is the differential of the functional j n . To solve the nonlinear system (3.16) we can use Newton's method as described below.
Let (ρ 0 , θ 0 ) be given in R 2 ; for k ≥ 0, we compute (ρ k+1 , θ k+1 ) from (ρ k , θ k ) via the solution of
div.formula: D 2 j(ρ k , θ k ) ρ k+1 -ρ k θ k+1 -θ k = -Dj(ρ k , θ k ), (3.17)
div.p: where D 2 j(ρ, θ) is the Jacobian of Dj at (ρ, θ).

An alternative to the above Newton's method can be found in [163]; numerical experiments show that this new algorithm is both faster and more robust than the Newton's method (3.17). Detailed comparisons between the two algorithms can be found in [38]. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php Remark 3.1. It is worth mentioning that an algorithm of the ALG2 type was used in [21] for the solution of the Monge-Kantorovich optimal transportation problem. To the best of our knowledge this is the first application of an augmented Lagrangian method to the solution of a fully nonlinear elliptic boundary value problem.

Remark 3.2. Algorithm (3.9) was obtained by applying to problem (3.7) a primal-dual algorithm called ALG2 by some practitioners ( [20,89,97] for example). To the best of our knowledge, ALG2 was introduced in the mid-1970s for the numerical solution of nonlinear (possibly nonsmooth and/or nonconvex) variational problems. Recently, ALG2 and closely related algorithms have seen a surge in their popularity under the name of ADMM (for alternating direction methods of multipliers), the main reason being (from our point of view) the applicability of these methods to a large variety of problems from image and data processing, and statistical learning, as shown in, e.g., [27,129,74] (see also the many references therein). Two important (related) properties of the family of primal-dual algorithms above are their ability to take advantage of the special structure of a problem (decomposition properties in particular) and their modularity. This was clear when solving problem (2.2); its solution was reduced to the solution of a sequence of much simpler linear and nonlinear problems, the differential problems all being linear and strongly elliptic with constant coefficients 3.1.3. Numerical Experiments. The mixed finite element implementation of the augmented Lagrangian algorithm (3.9) was discussed in [65,67,68]. Here we summarize the main numerical results and observations of [65]. Below, h denotes the mesh size and (u c h , p c h ) the computed mixed finite element approximations of (u, p). We consider below four test problems, all associated with Ω = (0, 1) 2 .
The first two test problems are defined as follows:

Moreover, the number of iterations required to achieve convergence increases slowly with h -1 (actually, slower than h -1/2 ). It is worth noticing that over Ω, the function u(x) = (2|x|) 3 2 /3 does not belong to C 2 (Ω), but since it belongs to W 2,p (Ω) for all p ∈ [1,4), it has enough regularity-in principle-to be captured by algorithm (3.9), which indeed is the case.
The third test problem is

The last test problem is given by det(D 2 u) = 1 in Ω, u= 0 on ∂Ω. (3.21) Despite the data being smooth, this problem has no smooth solutions, due to the nonstrict convexity of Ω. On the other hand, it has a unique viscosity solution. After applying the discrete variant of algorithm (3.9) to problem (3.21), the following phenomena are observed:

(i) For r sufficiently small (r = 1 here) the sequence {(u n h , p n h )} n converges geometrically (albeit slowly; the number of iterations required to achieve convergence increases in a rate which is proportional to h -1

2 ) to a limit (u c h , p c h ) belonging to V g × Q + f , while the sequence {λ n h } n diverges arithmetically. (ii) A close-up look at the graph of -u c h with h = 1 64 in Figure 3.1 (right) shows that the curvature of the graph becomes negative near the corners, which violates the Monge-Ampère equation (in the pointwise sense). div.head: A Least Squares Formulation for the Monge-Amp ère Problem (2.2).
div.p: A least squares methodology for the solution of the Monge-Ampère problem (2.2) was introduced in [65] and further discussed in [68,96]. Such a least squares formulation reads as follows: Find (u, p) (3.23) with V g and Q + f still defined by (3.7d) and (3.7e), and
div.formula: ∈ V g × Q + f such that j(u, p) ≤ j(v, q) ∀(v, q) ∈ V g × Q + f , (3.22) or (u, p) = argmin (v,q)∈Vg ×Q + f j(v, q),
div.p: Later in this section we shall present some numerical experiment results to show the effectiveness of the above least squares approach (see [66,69,96] for additional numerical results and further comments). Below, we give some insight into the least squares formulation.

Assume that (f, g) ; moreover, with this least squares approach, we will also be able to capture the smooth convex solutions of (2.2) (that is, those for which (3.25) holds) if such a solution exists.
div.formula: ∈ L 1 (Ω) × H 3 2 (Ω); we then have V g × Q + f = ∅. Problem (2.2) has convex solutions in H 2 (Ω) if and only if D 2 V g ∩ Q + f = ∅. (3
div.p: There are situations, shape design for example, where computing a smooth solution verifying the boundary conditions exactly is more important than strictly verify- ing the equation in the domain (as long as the equation is "almost" verified). It turns out that the least squares approach formulated above possesses such properties and thus provides an alternative to the viscosity solutions à la Crandall, Ishii, and Lions (see [56]). Remark 3.3. Using least squares methods for the solution of linear and nonlinear PDE problems is not a particularly new idea (see, for example, [95] and the references therein). However, this approach has enjoyed a strong surge in popularity during the last decade due to the ability of least squares methods to allow variational techniques for the solution to initially nonvariational problems. We refer the reader to [25] for a recent comprehensive exposition of the theory and practice of least squares methods for the numerical solution of PDE problems.

div.head: An Operator-Splitting Method for the Solution of (3.22).
div.p: When solving the least squares problem (3.22), it is quite natural to take advantage of its decomposition properties. We can use, for example, a block-relaxation method (cf. [95]) operating alternately between V g and Q + f , as is done in [38]. In this article, we will focus on the operator-splitting method discussed in [66,69,96]. To implement this method, it is very convenient to introduce the following equivalent formulation of problem (3.22):
div.formula: Find (u, p) ∈ V g × Q such that j + f (u, p) ≤ j + f (v, q) ∀{v, q} ∈ V g × Q, (3.26)
div.p: with Q still defined by (3.7f) and
div.formula: j + f (v, q) = j(v, q) + I + f (q), I + f (q) = 0 if q ∈ Q + f , +∞ if q ∈ Q\Q + f ,(3.27)
div.p: that is, I + f (•) is the indicator functional of the set Q + f . To solve the least squares problem (3.22), we will use the following strategy:
Step 1. Derive the Euler-Lagrange equation of (3.26).
Step 2. Associate with the above Euler-Lagrange equation an initial value problem (gradient flow) in V g × Q.
Step 3. Use operator splitting to discretize the gradient flow problem in time.
A variational formulation of the Euler-Lagrange equation of (3.26) reads as follows:
div.formula: Find (u, p) ∈ V g × Q such that Ω D 2 u -p : D 2 v -q dx + ∂I + f (p), q = 0 ∀(v, q) ∈ V 0 × Q, (3.28)
div.p: where V 0 = H 2 (Ω) ∩ H 1 0 (Ω) and ∂I + f (p) denotes a generalized differential at p of the functional I + f . Next, we associate with (3.28) the following initial value problem: For all t > 0, find (u(t),
div.formula: p(t)) ∈ V g × Q such that Ω ∂ ∂t (Δu)(Δv) dx + Ω D 2 u : D 2 v dx = Ω p : D 2 v dx ∀v ∈ V 0 , (3.29a) ∂p ∂t + p + ∂I + f (p) = D 2 u, (3.29b)
div.p: with initial conditions (u(0), p(0)) = (u 0 , p 0 ). Assuming that (u 0 , p 0 ) has been properly chosen (see below), we are going to capture the solution of (3.28)
div.formula: (u 0 , p 0 ) = (u 0 , p 0 ). Given (u n , p n ), define (u n+1 , p n+1 ) ∈ V g × Q as the solution of p n+1 -p n τ + p n+1 + ∂I + f (p n+1 ) = D 2 u n , (3.30a) Ω Δ u n+1 -u n τ Δv dx + Ω D 2 u n+1 : D 2 v dx (3.30b) = Ω p n+1 : D 2 v dx ∀v ∈ V 0 ,
div.p: with τ (≥ 0) a time-discretization step.
We conclude this subsection with a few comments on issues related to the implementation of the algorithm above.

Remark 3.4. (a) The initial guess (u 0 , p 0 ) in (3.29) and in its time-discretization scheme (3.30) must be chosen with care because it not only has an impact on the convergence of the algorithm, but may also play a role in selecting a solution for the least squares problem (3.23). Let λ 1 and λ 2 denote the eigenvalues of D 2 u. Then Δu = λ 1 +λ 2 and det(D 2 u) = λ 1 λ 2 . It follows from (2.2) that λ 1 λ 2 = f . Suppose that we look for a convex solution of (2.2); the relation
div.formula: λ 1 λ 2 = 1 4 (λ 1 + λ 2 ) 2 -(λ 1 -λ 2 ) 2 shows that if λ 1 and λ 2 are close, then Δu ≈ 2 √ f . This suggests choosing u 0 as the solution of Δu 0 ≈ 2 √ f in Ω with u 0 = g on ∂Ω.
div.p: Regarding p 0 , an obvious choice is
div.formula: p 0 = D 2 u 0 . Another choice is p 0 = √ fI 2×2 , which clearly belongs to Q + f . (b)
div.p: The subproblem (3.30a) can be interpreted as the Euler-Lagrange equation of the following minimization problem: Find
div.formula: p n+1 ∈ Q + f such that J n (p n+1 ) ≤ J n (q) ∀q ∈ Q + f , (3.31)
div.p: where (c) The subproblem (3.30b) belongs to the following family of linear variational biharmonic problems: Find u ∈ V g such that
div.formula: J n (q) = 1 2 (1 + τ ) Ω |q| 2 dx - Ω p n + τD 2 u n : q dx. (3
Ω ΔuΔv dx + τ Ω D 2 u : D 2 v dx = L(v) ∀v ∈ V 0 , (3.33)
div.p: where L(•) is a linear and continuous functional on H 2 (Ω). The conjugate gradient solution of linear variational problems such as (3.33) (and (3.11)) was addressed in [94, Chapter 3]. Such a conjugate gradient algorithm can be formulated for problem (3.33) in the spaces V g and V 0 both endowed with the scalar product (v, w) → Ω ΔvΔw dx and the induced norm. Combined with an appropriate mixed finite element approximation of problem (2.2) (see section 3.2.3), the algorithm requires solving two discrete Poisson problems at each iteration. We refer the reader to [69, section 6] for a detailed description.

div.head: A Mixed Finite Element Method for the Solution of Problem (2.2).
div.p: Due to their strong nonlinearity, integration by parts is either difficult or impossible Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php for fully nonlinear PDEs. As a result, direct formulations of Galerkin-type numerical methods such as finite element methods and DG methods are not feasible. To circumvent this difficulty, one idea is to first define some discrete (variational) derivatives offline and then to derive a numerical method by replacing (with possible variations) the derivatives which appear in the fully nonlinear PDE by their corresponding discrete derivatives.

In [69,66] Dean and Glowinski proposed such an approach for the Monge-Ampère problem (2.2). To avoid using complicated finite element subspaces of H 2 (Ω), mixed finite element spaces and methods, which are closely related to those discussed in [98,70] for the solution of linear and nonlinear biharmonic problems, were used to define the required discrete variational second order derivatives. It is interesting to note that these mixed finite element methods are also closely related to those discussed in section 4.3.2 for the implementation of the vanishing moment method. Based on this approach, it is possible to solve (2.2) using finite element spaces which are commonly used for second order elliptic problems.

To simplify matters, we assume that Ω is a bounded polygonal domain of R 2 . Let T h be a regular triangulation of Ω such as the one shown in Figure 3.1. Define the continuous linear finite element space V h = v v ∈ C 0 (Ω), v T ∈ P 1 (T ) ∀T ∈ T h , which will be used to approximate the infinite-dimensional spaces L 2 (Ω) and H 1 (Ω). Here, P 1 (T ) denotes the space of linear polynomials on T . For a given function
div.formula: v ∈ H 2 (Ω), we denote v xixj by D 2 ij (v). It follows from Green's formula that Ω D 2 ij (v)w dx = - 1 2 Ω v xi w xj + v xj w xi dx ∀w ∈ H 1 0 (Ω), 1 ≤ i, j ≤ 2. (3.34) Consider now v ∈ V h ; formula (3.34) allows us to uniquely define the discrete analogue D 2 hij : V h → V 0h := V h ∩ H 1 0 (Ω) of the differential operator D 2 ij by Ω D 2 hij (v)w dx = - 1 2 Ω v xi w xj + v xj w xi dx ∀w ∈ V 0h . (3.35)
div.p: To reduce the cost of computing the above discrete second order partial derivatives, numerical quadratures such as the trapezoidal rule may be employed to evaluate the integral on the left-hand side of (3.35). We refer the reader to [38,69] for more details and computational examples.
With the help of these discrete second order derivative formulas, the following scheme was proposed in [69, section 6] (also see [66]) to approximate the Monge-Ampère problem (2.2): Find
div.formula: u h ∈ V gh := v v ∈ V h , v(P ) = g(P ) ∀P ∈ Σ h ∩ ∂Ω such that D 2 h11 (u h )(P )D 2 h22 (u h )(P ) -D 2 h12 (u h )(P ) 2 = f h (P ) ∀P ∈ Σ 0h , (3.36)
div.p: where f h is some continuous positive approximation of f , and we implicitly assume that g is a continuous function on ∂Ω, which is the case when g ∈ H 3 2 (∂Ω). To solve the nonlinear algebraic system (3.36), the least squares solution is sought in [69] as follows. First, the spaces Q and Q + f are approximated, respectively, by
where
div.formula: D 2 h (v) = D 2 hij (v) 1≤i,j≤2 , q h = 1 3 P ∈Σ 0h
(u h , p h ) ∈ V gh × Q + fh such that j h (u h , p h ) ≤ j(v, q) ∀(v, q) ∈ V gh × Q + fh . (3.40)
div.p: We remark that the iterative algorithms introduced in section 3.2.2 for the least squares problem (3.23) can be easily adapted to the discrete least squares problem (3.40) as shown in [69, section 6.4].

div.head: Numerical Experiments.
div.p: In this section we present some illustrating numerical tests for the Monge-Ampère problems defined by (3.18), (3.19), (3.20), and (3.21), with Ω = (0, 1) 2 , using the least squares methodology as discussed in sections 3.2.1 to 3.2.3. We refer the reader to [66,69] for more extensive numerical tests and discussions. If the above mixed finite method is constructed on uniform triangulations T h such as the one shown in Figure 3.1, the solutions we obtain for the test problems (3.18), (3.19), (3.20) are essentially same as those obtained using the augmented Lagrangian approach. This is not surprising because these two methods just represent two different ways of solving the same discrete problem. As an illustration, we show in Table 3.1 some of the convergence results for the test problem (3.19), where the stopping criterion D 2 h (u n h ) -p n h 0,h ≤ 10 -6 is used in the experiments. In the table, n it denotes the number of iterations required to achieve convergence, and • 0,h is the same as in section 3.1.

Table 3.1 clearly suggests that (i), for τ large enough, the speed of convergence is essentially independent of τ ; (ii) the speed of convergence is essentially independent of h; and (iii) the L 2 (Ω)-norm error is of order O(h 2 ). Similar conclusions can be drawn from the numerical results for problems (3.18) and (3.20) (see [69] for details). A remarkable property of the least squares/operator-splitting methodology is its robustness with respect to the choice of τ , as soon as τ 1. The augmented Lagrangian methodology discussed in section 3.1 does not have this robustness property concerning the choice of the augmentation parameter r. Indeed, unlike some other applications of the augmented Lagrangian methodology (see [97,89]), the choice of r is critical for algorithm (3.9) to achieve good convergence.

Next, we apply the least squares methodology discussed in sections 3.2.1 to 3.2.3 to the (ill-posed) Monge-Ampère problem (3.21), using the same uniform triangulation T h as shown in Figure 3.1 and the criterion u n+1 h u n h 0,h ≤ 10 -7 to stop the iterations. The test results are displayed in Table 3.2.

It is clear from Table 3.2 that the convergence is much slower than for the test problems (3.18), (3.19), and (3.20). However some important features remain. For example, the number of iterations required to achieve convergence is essentially independent of τ as soon as it becomes large enough and increases slowly with 1 h . Other numerical experiments reported in [69] strongly suggest that u h converges superlinearly (with respect to h) to a limit u * which is a generalized solution (in a least squares sense) of problem (3.21).

We conclude this section with some remarks. Remark 3.5. (i) Let us denote by u AL,c h (resp., u LS,c h ) the computed approximate generalized solutions of problem (3.21) obtained by (with the same triangulation T h ) the discrete variant of the augmented Lagrangian algorithm (3.9) with r = 1 (resp., the discrete analogue of the least squares/operator-splitting methodology we employed to produce the results in Table 3.2). For all the values of h in Table 3.2, we have u AL,c h u LS,c h 0,h of the order of 10 -5 . This suggests that both functions u AL,c h and u LS,c h are approximations of the same function, namely, the generalized solution u * as mentioned above.

(ii) To examine the mesh effect, three different triangulations as shown in Figures 3.3 (a), (b), and (c) are considered in [38]. The numerical experiments reported in [38] lead to the following observations. For the test problems (3.18), (3.19), and (3.20) (and other test problems with known exact convex solutions having H 2 (Ω)-regularity), the computed solutions with triangulations of type (a) satisfy uu h 0,h = O(h 2 ) and ∇(uu h ) 0,h = O(h), which are optimal for piecewise linear finite element approximations. On the other hand, the convergence goes from poor, with triangulations of type (c), to very bad, with triangulations of type (b) (see [38] for details). Among the remedies proposed in [38] to improve these bad convergences, the simplest Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php one is that instead of using (3.35), the discrete second order derivatives are computed by
div.formula: C T ∈T h |T | T ∇D 2 hij (v) • ∇w dx + Ω D 2 hij (v)w dx (3.41) = - 1 2 Ω v xi w xj + v xj w xi dx ∀w ∈ V 0h ,
div.p: where |T | = meas(T ) and C = O( 1) is a positive constant. The numerical results obtained in [38] using (3.41) (including test problems where Ω has a partially or totally curved boundary) show optimal orders of convergence for both structured and unstructured triangulations including those of type (b). Conceptually, the stabilization procedure associated with (3.41) is reminiscent of a very popular one introduced in [70] for stabilizing discrete Stokes problems.

div.head: Other Fully Nonlinear Elliptic Equations.
div.p: In [66,96,44] the least squares methodology discussed in section 3.2 was also applied to the fully nonlinear Pucci's problem
div.formula: αλ + + λ -= 0 in Ω, u= g on ∂Ω, (3.42)
div.p: where Ω is a bounded domain of R 2 , α > 1 is a constant, and λ + and λ -denote the largest and the smallest eigenvalues of the Hessian D 2 u of the unknown function u. Discussion about the existence of viscosity solutions to (3.42) can be found in [43]. In order to apply the least squares methodology discussed in section 3.2 to (3.42), it was observed in [66,96,44] that the above problem is equivalent to the following system of partial differential relations:
div.formula: α|Δu| 2 + (α -1) 2 det(D 2 u) = 0 and Δu ≤ 0 in Ω, (3.43a) u = g on ∂Ω. (3.43b) A least squares formulation of (3.43) is defined as seeking (u, p) ∈ V g × C -such that j(u, p) ≤ j(v, q) ∀(v, q) ∈ V g × C -, (3.44) where j(v, q) = 1 2 Ω D 2 v -q 2 dx,
div.p: C -= q q ∈ Q, q 11 + q 22 ≤ 0, α|q 11 + q 22 | 2 + (α -1) 2 (q 11 q 22q 2 12 ) = 0 . Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php

The mixed finite element approximation of (3.43) and the iterative solution of the discrete analogue of problem (3.44) were discussed extensively in [66,96,44], where it was also shown that the least squares methodology is sufficiently robust to handle (without data smoothing) the situations where the boundary data g is the characteristic function of a subset Γ 1 of ∂Ω (i.e., g = 1 on Γ 1 , g = 0 on ∂Ω\Γ 1 ), a situation in which g does not have H

div.head: Formulation of the Vanishing Moment
div.p: Method.
