Unlike all the other numerical methods reviewed earlier that are aimed at constructing numerical schemes for computing the solutions of fully nonlinear second order PDEs, the vanishing moment method, which was first introduced in [84], aims to (constructively) approximate any given fully nonlinear second order PDE by a sequence of well-chosen higher order quasi-linear PDEs. Of course, when that is done, the consequence, which is clear and was indeed the motivation for proposing the vanishing moment method, is that the solutions of the higher order PDEs will converge to the weak solution of the underlying fully nonlinear second order PDE. As a result, the latter can be computed via the former by any numerical PDE method mentioned in section 1.3. In other words, the vanishing moment method focuses on approximating a "hard-to-handle" fully nonlinear PDE by an "easier-to-handle" quasi-linear PDE. It does not attach or relate to any particular numerical discretization technique. However, we have already mentioned in section 2.1.5 that the vanishing moment method provides an inspiration (in terms of designing numerical operators) for constructing convergent finite difference and DG methods (cf. [80,81]). In this section, we show that the vanishing moment method also provides much needed capability and an effective way for computing viscosity solutions of fully nonlinear second order PDEs using Galerkin-type numerical methods.

Let F [u](x) := F (D 2 u(x), ∇u(x), u(x), x) and suppose that -F is an elliptic differential operator in Ω in the sense of [93,Chapter 17]. Let Ω ⊂ R d (d ≥ 2) be a bounded domain and consider the Dirichlet problem
div.formula: F [u] = 0 in Ω, (4.1a) u = g on ∂Ω. (4.1b)
div.p: In full generality, the vanishing moment approximation of (4.1a) introduced in [84] reads as
div.formula: G ε [u ε ] + F [u ε ] = 0 in Ω, ε > 0, (4.2)
div.p: where G ε is some (unspecified) higher order (> 2) differential operator. Concerning the choice of the operator G ε , the following guidelines were proposed in [84]:
(i) G ε should be a linear or quasi-linear operator.
(ii) -G ε should be an elliptic operator.

(iii) G ε should "vanish" in some sense as ε → 0. (iv) Equation (4.2) should be "easy" to solve numerically. Although (i) allows the use of a quasi-linear operator G ε , in practice, it is better to choose a linear operator in order to meet the guideline (iv), as the "regularized" equation (4.2) has to be solved numerically in the end. (iii) is an obvious guideline. Finally, the guideline (ii) is natural. Since a scalar elliptic differential operator acting on real-valued functions must have an even order, the lowest order for G ε is four Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php [180]. When thinking about fourth order elliptic differential operators, the biharmonic operator stands out immediately. Making use of these observations, we are led to the selection [84,83,142] G ε [v] := -εΔ 2 v, (4.3) and (4.2) becomes
div.formula: εΔ 2 u ε -F [u ε ] = 0 in Ω, ε>0. (4.4a)
div.p: To complete the formulation of the vanishing moment method, the other critical issue that must be addressed is the choice of the boundary conditions. Obviously, the given Dirichlet boundary condition (4.1b) should be retained, and so we impose
div.formula: u ε = g on ∂Ω. (4.4b)
div.p: However, since (4.4a) is a fourth order PDE, (4.4b) is not sufficient for the wellposedness of (4.4a), and therefore another boundary condition must be imposed. In this regard, we have some leeway because several boundary conditions could be used for this purpose. On the other hand, physically and mathematically, any extra boundary condition will introduce a so-called boundary layer. A good choice would be one which gives-after space discretization-a boundary layer whose thickness is at most the order of the space discretization mesh size. Based on some heuristic arguments and evidence of numerical experiments (cf. [84,83,142]), it was concluded that second or higher order boundary conditions are better candidates for the job, and the following additional boundary conditions were recommended:
div.formula: (4.4c) Δu ε = ε or ∂Δu ε ∂n = ε or D 2 u ε n • n = ε on ∂Ω,
div.p: where n denotes the outward unit normal to ∂Ω. Remark 4.1. We note that the boundary value ε is chosen for convenience to ensure that Δu ε is strictly positive in Ω. The value ε can be replaced by any c ε > 0 satisfying c ε → 0 as ε → 0 + (see [83]). Moreover, our numerical experiments show that the vanishing method works equally well if all boundary conditions in (4.4c) are replaced by the homogeneous boundary conditions (i.e., set c ε = 0).

To summarize, (one version of) the vanishing moment method consists of approximating the (given) fully nonlinear second order Dirichlet problem (4.1) by the quasilinear fourth order boundary value problem (4.4). Moreover, the limit lim ε→0 + u ε (see section 4.2 for the precise meaning of the limit), if it exists, is called a moment solution of (4.1).

Clearly, the vanishing moment method is very much in the spirit of the vanishing viscosity method for fully nonlinear first order PDEs introduced in [58], and the notion of moment solutions for fully nonlinear second order PDEs is a natural extension of the (original) notion of viscosity solutions for fully nonlinear first order PDEs. We also remark that when d = 2, if u ε is interpreted as the vertical displacement of a bended plate, then D 2 u ε becomes the moment tensor of the plate. One of the commonly used weak forms of εΔ 2 u ε is ε(D 2 u ε , D 2 v), which is expected to vanish as ε → 0 + . This is the very reason why we call the above limiting process the vanishing moment method and call lim ε→0 + u ε a moment solution. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php

div.head: Theoretical Foundation of the Vanishing Moment Method.
div.p: As we have explained above, conceptually, the vanishing moment method is based on a very simple idea, that is, to approximate a "hard-to-handle" fully nonlinear lower order PDE by a family of "easier-to-handle" quasi-linear higher order PDEs. Clearly, such a limiting process is constructive and consequently, if it works, then it immediately can be utilized to develop all kinds of numerical methods for solving the original "hardto-handle" fully nonlinear PDE. To a large extent, this is the primary motivation for us to introduce the vanishing moment methodology in the first place [84]. We emphasize again that the vanishing moment method is neither attached to nor limited to any numerical discretization technique, although being able to use Galerkin-type numerical methods to solve the "regularized" problem (hence, to solve the original fully nonlinear problem indirectly) was another motivation (see [84]).

A natural and critical question is whether the vanishing moment method works. Specifically, the following questions need to be answered: (i) Does the limit lim ε→0 + u ε exist and in what sense? (ii) What are the rates of convergence? (iii) Do moment solutions relate to viscosity solutions and how? Clearly all these questions are theoretical PDE questions, and none of them seem easy to answer (especially in general). It should be emphasized that, unlike the vanishing viscosity method [58], the higher order vanishing moment approximation (4.4a) does not in general retain the maximum principle enjoyed by the original fully nonlinear second order PDE (4.1a). The loss of the maximum principle makes it much more difficult to derive a priori estimates for u ε . The situation is even worse for the Monge-Ampère-type equations because one would lose the sign control on the fully nonlinear term det D 2 u ε unless, miraculously, u ε itself is a convex function (which turns out to be the case). There are two ways to address the questions above. The first is the scientific computing approach, which means performing many numerical experiments to see if the methodology works in practice, which is indeed the case so far. The other is the traditional theoretical analysis approach, which is necessary in order to give a definitive answer to each of the above question.

The known theoretical PDE results so far have only been obtained for the Dirichlet Monge-Ampère-type problems, and all the results are uniformly positive in supporting the vanishing moment method as an efficient methodology for approximating the unique (convex) viscosity solution to Monge-Ampère-type problems. In what follows, we shall briefly summarize some of the main results and refer the reader to [84,83,142] and the references therein for further details.
In the case of the Monge-Ampère equation, the vanishing moment method approximates det(
div.formula: D 2 u) = f (≥ 0) in Ω, (4.5a) u = g on ∂Ω (4.5b) by εΔ 2 u ε -det(D 2 u ε ) = -f in Ω, (4.6a) u ε = g on ∂Ω, (4.6b) Δu ε = ε on ∂Ω. (4.6c)
div.p: Note that the condition f ≥ 0 is necessary for (4.5) to have a convex solution.

A complete convergence theory for the vanishing moment problem (4.6) was established in the d-dimensional radially symmetric case for all d ≥ 2 in [83]. The results obtained there provide positive answers to the convergence questions (i)-(iii) raised above in the radially symmetric case. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php
div.formula: (ii) u ε r converges to u 0 r weakly * in L ∞ ((0, R)) as ε → 0 + . (iii) u 0 ≡ u.
div.p: An immediate consequence of parts (i) and (ii) of the theorem is the existence of moment solutions to the Monge-Ampère problem (4.5). It also reveals the meaning of lim ε→0 + u ε , that is, it should be understood in the pointwise sense with uniform convergence on compact subsets and weak convergence in H 1 . Part (iii) implies that moment solutions are unique and the (convex) moment solution must coincide with the (convex) viscosity solution whenever the latter exists and is unique.

Once the convergence of u ε has been established, the final theoretical issue concerns the rate(s) of convergence. Before addressing this issue, it should be noted that obtaining rates of convergence is possible only when a function or solution to be approximated has some minimum regularities. This regularity requirement applies not only to discrete or numerical approximations, but also to nondiscrete approximations. It is easy to see that one would not expect any rate of convergence for the vanishing moment method if the viscosity solution u of (4.5) had no regularity beyond C 0 ∩ H 1 , because u itself does not satisfy the PDE in any tangible sense. However, for more regular u, the following rates of convergence were derived in [83].

Theorem 4.4 (see Theorem 3.19 of [83]). Let u denote the strictly convex viscosity solution to problem (4.5) and u ε be a classical solution to problem (4.6). Suppose that u ∈ W 2,∞ (Ω) ∩ H 3 (Ω) and u ε is either convex or "almost convex" 7 in Ω. Then the following estimates hold:
div.formula: ∇(u -u ε ) L 2 (Ω) ≤ Cε 3 4 , (4.7a) Δ(u -u ε ) L 2 (Ω) ≤ Cε 1 4 , (4.7b) u -u ε L 2 (Ω) ≤ Cε, (4.7c) where C = C( u H 3 (Ω) ) is a positive ε-independent constant.
div.p: We remark that the conclusions of Theorem 4.4 hold in any dimension and for any domain as long as the regularity assumptions on u and u ε are fulfilled. As expected, radially symmetric counterparts of the above three estimates were also derived in [83].

In that case all the assumptions on u and u ε stated in the theorem were verified. It is also interesting to note that (4.7c) was obtained using a duality argument in the PDE setting, which is similar to the well-known Aubin-Nitsche duality argument used in the finite element context (cf. [33,53]).

Another interesting feature of the vanishing moment method, which was first discovered accidentally by numerical experiments in [84] and later proved in [83], is its ability to "pick up" the unique concave solution of the Monge-Ampère problem (4.5) in the case of even dimension (i.e., d is a positive even integer). This can easily be achieved by substituting ε (> 0) with -ε (< 0) in (4.6a). In other words, the penalty parameter ε is driven to zero from the negative side in (4.6a) in order to approximate the concave solution.

Finally, we note that one of the near-term goals and the focus of current research on the theory of the vanishing moment method is to extend the a priori estimates and the convergence results of Theorems 4.1-4.3 for the radially symmetric case to the general domain case for problem (4.6). Another goal is to establish convergence theory for the general vanishing moment approximation (4.4) under some structure conditions on the function F similar to those proposed in [83,Chapters 4 and 5].
Furthermore, extensions of the vanishing moment methods to Bellman-type equations and to fully nonlinear second order parabolic PDEs were recently studied in [82].

div.head: Finite Element Implementation of the Vanishing Moment Method.
div.p: As mentioned earlier, the motivation behind introducing the vanishing moment method was to use it as a bridge to the ultimate goal of approximating viscosity solutions of fully nonlinear second order PDEs. The method allows one to approximate a "hardto-handle" fully nonlinear (lower order) PDE by a family of "easy-to-handle" quasilinear (higher order) PDEs. The numerical consequence of this approach is important because it frees up all the well-known numerical PDE methods summarized in section 1.3. In particular, the Galerkin-type methods can be used to solve fully nonlinear second order PDEs. It should be noted that because the vanishing moment method has the built-in capability to select the "right" solution, there is no need to use special grids or special techniques and schemes to discretize the vanishing moment equations. Standard grids and straightforward formulations of these well-known numerical PDE methods are all that is required. Moreover, the vanishing moment method approach allows one to use the wealth of existing computer codes developed for biharmonictype problems to compute viscosity solutions of fully nonlinear second order PDEs. As such, it is relatively easy to implement on computers.

div.head: Conforming Finite Element Methods.
div.p: In what follows, we shall first briefly describe a framework based on the combination of the vanishing moment method with a finite element method for solving fully nonlinear second order PDEs and then summarize the latest developments in convergence analysis and error estimation for the proposed methodology. Recall that our goal is to solve problem (4.4a)-(4.4c) 1 for a fixed (small) ε > 0, where here and in what follows, (4.4c) 1 refers to the 1st equality of (4.4c), etc. Since (4.4a) is quasi-linear, we can easily derive its weak formulation using the integration by parts approach: Find
div.formula: u ε ∈ V g := v ∈ H 2 (Ω); v ∂Ω = g such that for all v ∈ V 0 := H 2 (Ω) ∩ H 1 0 (Ω) there holds ε Ω Δu ε Δv dx - Ω F [u ε ]v dx = ε 2 ∂Ω ∂v ∂n ds. (4.8)
div.p: If it exists, such a u ε is naturally called a weak solution of (4.4a)-(4.4c) 1 .

The formulation of finite element methods for (4.8) is conceptually straightforward. For simplicity we assume that Ω is a polygonal or polyhedral domain. Let T h be a quasi-uniform "triangular" or "rectangular" partition of Ω (T h consists of tetrahedra or three-dimensional rectangles in the case d = 3) and V h ⊂ H 2 (Ω) be any conforming finite element space consisting of piecewise polynomials of degree k(> 1) satisfying, for any
div.formula: v ∈ H m (Ω), m ≥ 2, inf v h ∈V h v -v h H j ≤ Ch -j v H , j = 0, 1, 2, = min{m, k + 1}.
div.p: Then the finite element method is defined as seeking
div.formula: u ε h ∈ V h g := {v h ∈ V h ; (v h - g h )| ∂Ω = 0} such that ε Ω Δu ε h Δv h dx - Ω F [u ε h ]v h dx = ε 2 ∂Ω ∂v h ∂n ds ∀v h ∈ V h 0 := V h ∩ H 1 0 (Ω), (4.9)
div.p: where g h ∈ V h denotes some approximation of g. The finite element interpolation and the L 2 projection of g are two possible choices. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php Momentarily, let us assume that problem (4.9) has a unique solution u ε h . Then the framework we propose here is to approximate the unique viscosity solution u of (4.1) by u ε h via u ε . For any norm • in which u is defined, the triangle inequality immediately gives
div.formula: u -u ε h ≤ u -u ε + u ε -u ε h . (4.10)
div.p: Clearly, the first term on the right-hand side measures the error of the vanishing moment approximation. As was shown in section 4.2, this term is expected to tend to zero as ε → 0 + either without a rate if u is merely a viscosity solution or with a rate (in powers of ε) if u has some additional regularity properties (see Theorems 4.3 and 4.4). We emphasize that this term is independent of the numerical method in question. On the other hand, the second term on the right-hand side of (4.10), which measures the error due to the numerical method, is solely determined by the numerical method in question. When u ε is sufficiently smooth, a rate of convergence in powers of h is expected for this error term. Putting the above arguments together we get
div.formula: u -u ε h ≤ M 1 (ε) + M 2 (ε)h r (4.11)
div.p: for some constant r > 0, where
div.formula: lim ε→0 + M 1 (ε) = 0, lim ε→0 + M 2 (ε) = ∞.
div.p: The reason that M 2 blows up as
div.formula: ε → 0 + is that M 2 depends on the norm u ε H m (Ω)
div.p: for m ≥ 2 and this norm blows up in some negative power of ε (cf. [83]). The term M 1 (ε) is a bound for the error of the vanishing moment method; it can be expressed as a positive power of ε if u is sufficiently smooth (see Theorem 4.4).

To summarize, we have outlined a framework for constructing numerical methods for problem (4.1a) based on the combination of the vanishing moment method with a finite element method. When a specific finite element has been selected, the main tasks in completing the framework are (i) to verify the unique solvability of the finite element scheme (4.9), and (ii) to find r and M 2 in the general error estimate (4.11).
To show an example, we now cite a result of [87] for the Monge-Ampère problem (4.5) when it is approximated by the vanishing moment method combined with the Argyris finite element method.

Theorem 4.5 (see Theorems 4.3 and 4.4 of [87]). Let d = 2 and V h ⊂ H 2 (Ω) denote the Argyris finite element space [53,Chapter 6], and suppose u ε ∈ H m (Ω). Then there exists an h 0 > 0 such that there exists a unique solution
div.formula: u ε h ∈ V h g to problem (4.9) with F [v] = det(D 2 v) -f for h ∈ (0, h 0 ). Furthermore, u ε h satisfies the error estimates u ε -u ε h H 2 ≤ C 1 (ε)h -2 u ε H , (4.12) u ε -u ε h L 2 ≤ C 2 (ε) h u ε H l + h 2 -4 u ε 2 H , = min{6, m}, (4.13)
div.p: where C 1 (ε) and C 2 (ε) are two positive constants that depend on ε -1 in some low polynomial orders. Remark 4.2. (a) Both error estimates are optimal in h. The constants C 1 (ε) and C 2 (ε) provide M 2 (ε) in the general error estimate (4.11) for the H 2 and L 2 norms, respectively.

(b) To derive the energy norm error estimate (4.12), a nonstandard error analysis technique is required because the standard perturbation error analysis technique does Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php not apply here. To see this, we write the error equation as
div.formula: ε Ω Δ(u ε -u ε h )Δv h dx - Ω det(D 2 u ε ) -det(D 2 u ε h ) v h dx = 0 ∀v h ∈ V h 0 .
div.p: Since the nonlinear term in the left-hand side does not give a positive contribution (after choosing an appropriate test function v h ), and since it is too strong to be controlled by the biharmonic term, one cannot get any error estimate directly from the error equation. To overcome this difficulty, the main idea of [87], which is also adopted in [31,32,140], is to analyze and make use of the linearization of the vanishing moment equation (4.6a) at the solution u ε to design a fixed point argument. This nonstandard error analysis technique proves the existence and uniqueness as well as the energy norm error estimate (4.12) simultaneously.

(c) The results of the above theorem have recently been extended to general fully nonlinear second order (elliptic) PDEs (4.1a) under some structure assumptions on the nonlinear function F in [83,Chapter 4]. The general framework developed there covers the Monge-Ampère equation, the prescribed Gauss curvature equation, and the infinity-Laplace equation as three specific examples.

div.head: Mixed Finite Element Methods.
div.p: Since the natural energy space for the vanishing moment equation (4.4a) is H 2 (Ω) (as it was for the augmented Lagrangian and least squares methods discussed in section 3), it is well known [53] that a conforming finite element subspace of H 2 (Ω) must be a subspace of C 1 (Ω). Constructing such a finite element space has proved to be very delicate and difficult, and only a handful of two-dimensional C 1 finite element spaces are known in the literature (cf. [53,Chapter 6]). Although it is doable, no three-dimensional C 1 finite element approximations are used in practice because of the large number of degrees of freedom required by the corresponding finite element spaces. Alternatively, mixed finite element methods have been extensively developed and used for solving biharmonic type (and general fourth order) PDEs in two dimensions (cf. [53,34,98]). Recall that the mixed formulation of (4.4) is based on rewriting this fourth order PDE as a system of two second order PDEs. By decoupling (4.4a) as a system, one is able to approximate (4.4a)-(4.4c) 3 8 using only C 0 finite elements, as opposed to computationally expensive and complicated C 1 finite elements. Another advantage of mixed finite element methods is that although they were originally developed for two-dimensional biharmonic problems, they can be easily extended to the three-dimensional case (cf. [85]).

Several popular mixed formulations for fourth order problems have been described in the literature (cf. [34,79]). However, since the Hessian matrix appears in (4.4a) and (4.6a) in a nonlinear fashion, Δu ε cannot be used as an additional unknown in a mixed formulation. This observation then rules out the popular family of Ciarlet-Raviart mixed finite element methods. On the other hand, it suggests the introduction of σ ε := D 2 u ε as an additional unknown, which then leads to the adoption of either the Hermann-Miyoshi mixed finite element method or the Hermann-Johnson mixed finite element method for solving problem (4.4a)-(4.4c) 3 .
Following [85,83], we rewrite (4.4a) as a system of two second order equations
div.formula: σ ε -D 2 u ε = 0, εΔtr(σ ε ) -F [σ ε , u ε ] = 0,
div.p: where tr(σ ε ) denotes the trace of σ ε and F
div.formula: [σ ε , u ε ](x) := F (σ ε (x), ∇u ε (x), u ε (x), x).
div.p: Then the Hermann-Miyoshi mixed formulation for (4.4a)-(4.4c) 3 reads as follows:
div.formula: Find (σ ε , u ε ) ∈ W ε × V g such that Ω σ ε : μ dx + Ω div (μ) • ∇u ε dx = d-1 i=1 ∂Ω ∂g ∂τ i μn • τ i ds ∀μ ∈ W 0 , (4.14a) ε Ω div (σ ε ) • ∇v dx + Ω F [σ ε , u ε ]v dx = 0 ∀v ∈ V 0 , (4.14b)
div.p: where
div.formula: W ε = μ ∈ W ; μn • n ∂Ω = ε , W 0 = μ ∈ W ; μn • n ∂Ω = 0 , W = μ ∈ H 1 (Ω)] d×d ; μ ij = μ ji , V g = {v ∈ H 1 (Ω); v| ∂Ω = g}, V 0 = H 1 0 (Ω), and {τ i } d-1 i=1
div.p: denotes an orthogonal (tangent) coordinate frame on ∂Ω.
Let T h be a quasi-uniform mesh over Ω and denote by V h ⊂ H 1 (Ω) the space of continuous, piecewise polynomials of degree k ≥ 2 over Ω. Also let
div.formula: V h g = v h ∈ V h ; v h ∂Ω = g h , V h 0 = V h ∩ H 1 0 (Ω), W h = V h d×d ∩ W , W h ε = W h ∩ W ε , and W h 0 ∩ W h ∩ W 0 .
div.p: The following Hermann-Miyoshi-type mixed finite element method was proposed in [85,83]:
div.formula: Find (σ ε h , u ε h ) ∈ W h ε × V h g such that for all μ h ∈ W h 0 and v h ∈ V 0 , Ω σ ε h : μ h dx + Ω div (μ h ) • ∇u ε h dx = d-1 i=1 ∂Ω ∂g h ∂τ i μ h n • τ i ds, (4.15a) ε Ω div (σ ε h ) • ∇v h dx + Ω F [σ ε h , u ε ]v h dx = 0. (4.15b)
div.p: We remark that the above choice of V h and W h is known to satisfy an inf-sup condition (cf. [34,79,85,151]).

Clearly, the general error estimate (4.11) still applies to mixed finite element approximations. In addition, there holds a similar estimate for σ ε h (assuming that u is sufficiently smooth so that σ is defined), that is,
div.formula: σ -σ ε h ≤ M 3 (ε) + M 4 (ε)h s (4.16)
div.p: for some constant s > 0 and lim
Again, to show a concrete example, we cite a result from [85] for the Monge-Ampère problem (4.5). Theorem 4.6 (cf. Theorems 4.1 and 4.2 of [85]).
div.formula: Let F [u] = det(D 2 u) -f . Sup- pose the solution of problem (4.6a)-(4.6b), (4.4c) 3 satisfies (u ε , σ ε ) ∈ H m × [H m ] d×d .
div.p: Then there exists h 0 > 0 such that for h ∈ (0, h 0 ) the approximate problem (4.15) has a unique solution
div.formula: (σ ε h , u ε h ) ∈ W h ε × V h g .
div.p: Moreover, the following error estimates hold:
div.formula: h σ ε -σ ε h L 2 + ε 2 u ε -u ε h H 1 ≤ C 3 (ε)h -1 ( σ ε H + u ε H ) , (4.17) σ ε -σ ε h H 1 ≤ C 4 (ε)h -3 σ ε H + u ε H , (4.18)
div.p: where = min{k + 1, m} and C 3 (ε) and C 4 (ε) are two positive constants that depend on ε -1 in some lower polynomial order. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php Remark 4.3. (a) Similar to the proof of Theorem 4.5, a nonstandard error analysis technique, which combines the linearization of the nonlinear mixed formulation with a fixed point argument, was utilized. However, the fixed point argument is a lot more complicated than the one used for conforming finite element methods due to a difficulty caused by the discrepancy between σ ε h and D 2 u ε h . Note that D 2 u ε h is not globally defined (in general, it is a measure but not a function).

(b) Similar to the conforming finite element case, the results of the above theorem have been extended to the general fully nonlinear second order (elliptic) PDE (4.1a) in [83,Chapter 4] under some structure assumptions on the nonlinear function F including the degenerate case. The general framework developed there covers the Monge-Ampère equation, the prescribed Gauss curvature equation, and the infinity-Laplace equation as three special examples.

(c) As a final comment, we note that since the Hermann-Miyoshi mixed finite element method computes both u ε h and σ ε h , the general perception being that the mixed method is computationally more expensive than conforming finite element methods because it needs to compute an additional unknown σ ε h . However, the numerical experiments reported in [84,85,83] all show that the opposite is true. In fact, the Hermann-Miyoshi mixed finite element method is much faster than the Argyris conforming finite element method. For some test problems, the former is 20 times faster than the latter in terms of CPU times. The superiority of the mixed method is most likely due to the simpler structure of its finite element spaces.

div.head: Other Numerical Methods.
div.p: In addition to the conforming and mixed finite element methods, a few other discretization methods have also been proposed (and analyzed) in the literature for approximating the vanishing moment problem (4.4a)-(4.4c) and/or (4.6a)-(4.6c). In [87] the spectral Galerkin method was proposed. Its formulation and convergence analysis are essentially the same as those for conforming finite element methods and they were indeed embedded in the formulation and analysis of conforming finite element methods in [87].

To avoid using complicated C 1 conforming finite element methods, nonconforming finite element methods were extensively developed in the 1970s and widely used for solving the biharmonic equation (cf. [53,Chapter 6]). In [142,141] the Morley nonconforming finite element was constructed and optimal order error estimates were also derived for approximating problem (4.6).

Finally, to completely avoid using special conforming, nonconforming, and mixed finite element methods, DG methods can be used to discretize problem (4.4), based on either the primary formulation or the mixed formulation. IP-DG methods of both types were proposed in [141] (also see [84]); however, their convergence analysis and error estimates have yet to be established.

div.head: Sample Numerical Experiments.
div.p: In this subsection we present some numerical experiment results obtained by the numerical methods based on the vanishing moment methodology as discussed in this section. Many of the examples below are taken from [141,83].

In the first experiment, we perform some numerical tests of the vanishing moment methodology in the radially symmetric case. To this end, we solve the radial version of (4.6) in the domain Ω = B(0, 1) using Hermite cubic finite element spaces. As data, we choose f = (1 + r 2 )e dr 2 /2 (r = |x|), g = e 1/2 so that the exact solution is u = e r 2 /2 . We plot u ε r , u ε rr , and the Laplacian Δu ε = u ε rr + d-1 r u ε r in two and Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php four dimensions in Figures 4.1-4.3 with ε-values 10 -1 , 10 -3 , 10 -5 and fixed h = 4 × 10 -3 . We observe from Figures 4.1 and 4.3 that u ε r > 0 and Δu ε > 0, which is in accordance with Theorem 4.1. We also see from Figure 4.2 that u ε rr is positive except for an ε-neighborhood of the boundary. Noting that the Hessian matrix of u ε has two distinct eigenvalues, u ε rr and 1 r u ε r , we conclude that u ε is convex except for this small neighborhood of the boundary. This is exactly what is stated in Theorem 4.2.
For our second experiment, we consider (4.6) with Ω = (0, 1) 2 . We choose our data such that the exact solution of (2.2) is given by u

). We note that u has a singularity at the corner (x 1 , x 2 ) = (1, 1) and has only the regularity u ∈ W 1,p (Ω) for all p ∈ [1,4). As such, this is a particularly challenging example to test the vanishing moment methodology. We compute u ε using the conforming finite element method (4.9) with the Argyris finite element space with parameters ε = 10 -4 and h = 10 -2 . We plot the computed solution and error in Figure 4.4. The numerical experiment indicates that (i) the vanishing moment methodology captures the convex solution, (ii) it accurately approximates the viscosity solution even when the exact solution is not smooth, and (iii) the error is concentrated at the singularity of u. We also mention that the numerical experiments presented in [141] indicated that for this particular example, u -
div.formula: u ε L 2 = O(ε) and u -u ε H 1 = O(ε 3/4
div.p: ). These rates of convergence are the same as in the radially symmetric case (see (4.7)), but a theoretical proof of such a result in the general case has not yet been shown.
For the next test, we solve the equation of prescribed Gauss curvature using the Hermann-Miyoshi fixed formulation (4.15). We compute
div.formula: F [σ ε h , u ε ] = det(σ ε )(1 + |∇u ε | 2 ) -d+2 2
div.p: -K for fixed ε = 10 -4 and h = 3 × 10 -2 and vary the Gauss curvature K. We choose the boundary condition to be g = 1x 2 1x 2 2 on the domain Ω = (-0.57, 0.57) 2 . We plot the results in Figure 4.5. The numerical experiment indicates that K max (the largest Gauss curvature for the given g and Ω) is 2.07.
For the last numerical experiment, we compute the solution to the infinity-Laplace equation (see (5.15) in section 5.11) using the mixed formulation (4.15) on the domain Ω = (-0.5, 0.5) 2 . We set
div.formula: F [σ ε , u ε ] = σ ε ∇u ε • ∇u ε in (4.
u -u ε L 2 = O(ε 2/3 ), u -u ε H 1 = O(ε 1/3
div.p: ). 4.5.2. Some Practical Issues. In this final subsection we discuss some practical implementation issues related to the vanishing moment methodology. The first issue is how to solve the discretized equations such as (4.9) and (4.14). As these are highly nonlinear algebraic systems, Newton's method would be a natural choice. However, a good initial guess is often required to guarantee the convergence of Newton's method, which is also the case for (4.9) and (4.14). One effective strategy which was developed and used in [84,85,86,87,83] is a "multiresolution" or "homotopy" strategy: first compute a numerical solution using a relatively large ε, and then use the computed solution as a starting value for Newton's method at a finer resolution ε. The process may need to be iterated in ε for more than one step. Our experiences show that (i) Newton's method is not sensitive to the initial guess for large values of ε (e.g., ε = 10 -1 ) and (ii) 1-3 steps are sufficient to generate a good starting value for the Newton method at the finest resolution ε at which one wants to compute a solution. Clearly, being able to design such an effective "homotopy" strategy is another advantage of the vanishing moment method. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php Another issue which needs to be addressed is the "boundary layer" issue due to the introduction of the extra boundary condition (4.4c) (or its homogeneous variants) As Theorem 4.2 shows, the "boundary layer" is well behaved and contained in an εneighborhood of the physical boundary. Moreover, numerical experiments in [84,83] show that the numerical errors in the "boundary layer" are often larger than those Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php in the remaining part of the domain, which is expected. To take advantage of this information, in [83] we proposed an iterative surgical strategy. Roughly speaking, the strategy, which is based on the predictor-corrector idea, involves a three-step surgical procedure: First, cut off the initially computed solution in an ε-neighborhood of the physical boundary; second, extrapolate the computed solution from the inner boundary of the ε-neighborhood to the outer boundary of the ε-neighborhood; third, compute the solution again using the new boundary condition (of the same type) in place of the boundary condition (4.4c). The procedure can be repeated. The second step involves an extrapolating process which projects the discontinuous piecewise polynomial function Δu ε h onto the continuous piecewise linear finite element space. To explain this process in further detail, we let Ω ε ⊂ Ω with dist(Ω ε , Ω) ≈ and denote by {x i } the vertices of the mesh. Let u pre h := u ε h denote a computed solution with the boundary condition (4.4c) (i.e., a "predicted" value), namely, u pre h satisfies for any
div.formula: v h ∈ V h 0 ε Ω Δu pre h Δv h dx - Ω det(D 2 u pre h )v h dx = -f v h dx + ε 2 ∂Ω ∂v h ∂n ds.
div.p: Using u pre h we construct a piecewise linear function q h ∈ C 0 (Ω) such that for a vertex x i ∈ Ω ε , q h (x i ) equals {Δu pre h }(x i ), the average of Δu h at x i . For x i ∈ Ω\Ω ε , q h (x i ) is set to be {Δu pre h } evaluated at the closest grid point in Ω ε from x i . The third step in the iterative surgical strategy described above is to solve the problem again after replacing ε by q h in (4.4c), that is, we compute a "corrected" solution u cor h by
div.formula: ε Ω Δu cor h Δv h dx - Ω det(D 2 u cor h )v h dx = -f v h dx + ε ∂Ω q h ∂v h ∂n ds
div.p: for any v h ∈ V h 0 . The numerical tests in [83] show that the global error in every norm (i.e., H k -norm for k = 0, 1, 2) is reduced by nearly a factor of 10 just by performing one iteration of the iterative surgical strategy.

div.head: Applications.
div.p: In this section we briefly describe a number of application problems which give rise to fully nonlinear second order PDEs. We also point out recent numerical works, if there are any, for each application. Due to page limitations, several Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php other applications such as antenna design, geometric optics, economics, and k-surfaces could not be included. The interested reader is referred to [45,39,42,46,118,164,174] for further discussions.

5.1. Monge-Amp ère Problem and Monge-Amp ère Equation. The Monge-Ampère problem, which was described in section 2.1.1, seeks to find a continuous convex function u such that the Monge-Ampère measure M u of u equals a given Radon measure μ. In the case that the Radon measure has a density f (with respect to the Lebesgue measure), the Monge-Ampère problem then reduces to the Monge-Ampère equation det(D 2 u) = f . The Monge-Ampère equation is without question the best-known fully nonlinear second order PDE. It is to fully nonlinear second order PDEs what the Poisson equation is to linear second order PDEs. What we shall see in the remainder of this section is that the Monge-Ampère equation and its variations arise from various applications including astrophysics, computer science, differential geometry, image processing, finance, optimal transportation, and geophysics. From the discussions in sections 2-4, we also see that most numerical methods and algorithms for fully nonlinear second order PDEs have either been specifically designed for the Monge-Ampère equation [22,67,68,92,147,148] or are applicable to the Monge-Ampère equation [12,31,32,84,83,87,85]. To a large extent, the Monge-Ampère equation serves both as a prototype of fully nonlinear second order PDEs for developing numerical techniques and as a benchmark problem to test whether a numerical method works.

div.head: The Minkowski Problem and the Equation of Prescribed Gauss Curvature.
div.p: Let Ω ⊂ R d be a bounded domain and g ∈ C 0 (∂Ω). For a given constant K > 0, the simplest version of the Minkowski problem (cf. [51,100,101,103,104,102,174]) seeks to find a function u whose graph (as a manifold) has constant Gauss curvature K and u takes the value g on ∂Ω. Recall that the Gauss curvature of the graph of u is given by the formula (cf. [93, section 14.6])
Thus, if the desired function u exists, it must satisfy

in Ω, (5.1a) u = g on ∂Ω. (5.1b) Equation (5.1a), which is called the equation of prescribed Gauss curvature, is a fully nonlinear Monge-Ampère-type equation of the form det(D 2 u) = f (∇u, u, x). It is known [100] that there exists a constant K max > 0 such that for each K ∈ [0, K max ), problem (5.1) has a unique convex viscosity solution. Theoretically, it is very difficult to give an accurate estimate for the upper bound K max , and so numerical approximations seem to be the only feasible way to find an accurate upper bound for K max .

There are very few numerical works in the literature which specifically deal with problem (5.1). Baginski and Whitaker [8] proposed a finite difference method for solving the problem in two-dimensions; see section 2.1.6 for a detailed description. The main idea of [8] is to mimic the method of continuity, which is used to prove the existence of solutions to the PDE problem, at the discrete level. The proposed numerical scheme requires the solution of a sequence of Monge-Ampère problems, which is expensive, and the discrete method of continuity is often not stable as the Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php parameter t tends to 1. Several numerical experiments were given in [8] but no convergence results were provided. As it was mentioned earlier in sections 4.3.1-4.3.2, the vanishing moment method was also formulated and applied to solving (5.1) in [84,83,141]. Both conforming and mixed finite element methods were developed and error estimates were derived for each of these finite element methods. Numerical experiments showed that the combined vanishing moment method and the standard or mixed finite element methods work very well for problem (5.1). On the other hand, the convergence of the vanishing moment approximation has yet to be established for problem (5.1). We also note that the numerical methods proposed in [67,68,31,32,140] for the Monge-Ampère problem (4.5a)-(4.5b) can potentially be extended to computing classical solutions of problem (5.1).

div.head: Affine Differential Geometry Applications.
div.p: Let M be the graph of a convex function u over Ω ⊂ R d , and denote by K(x) the Gaussian curvature of M at (x, u(x)) for x ∈ Ω. The affine area functional (cf. [171,172,177]) is then defined as
div.formula: A(u) := M K 1 d+2 = Ω det(D 2 u) 1 d+2 .
div.p: The graph of a convex function u is called affine maximal if u is a stationary point for the functional A. It can be shown [177] that u satisfies the Euler-Lagrange equations det(D 2 u) = w d+2 d+1 , (5.2a) tr cof(D 2 u)D 2 w = 0, (5.2b) where cof(D 2 u) denotes the cofactor matrix of D 2 u and tr(•) stands for the matrix trace operator. If w is eliminated from the system, then one obtains a highly nonlinear fourth order PDE in u. From a computational viewpoint, it seems better to keep the above system as it is, namely, coupling the Monge-Ampère equation and a second order linear equation.
No numerical work on solving (5.2) has been reported in the literature except the following vanishing moment approximation proposed by the first and the third authors in [84]:
div.formula: -εΔ 2 u ε + det(D 2 u ε ) = (w ε ) d+2 d+1 , tr cof(D 2 u ε )D 2 w ε = 0,
div.p: which was then discretized by finite element and mixed finite element methods. The numerical experiments show that this approach works very well. The numerical results also suggest that u ε is strictly convex, which is desired. Consequently, the w-equation is uniformly elliptic. This may explain why the above approach based on the combination of the vanishing moment method with finite element methods works so well; it also provides optimism for a possible convergence proof for the proposed vanishing moment methodology.

div.head: Monge-Kantorovich Optimal Transport Problem.
div.p: The Monge-Kantorovich (MK) optimal transport problem has received considerable attention in recent years (cf. [2,3,45,77,172,173,175,176] and the references therein). In general, the MK problem asks the following: Given two sets of equal volume, find the optimal masspreserving mapping between them, where optimality is measured by a given positive Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php cost density. Let f 1 and f 2 be two density functions, and let dμ 1 (x) = f 1 (x)dx and dμ 2 (y) = f 2 (y)dy denote two measures on R d . Set X := supp(f 1 ) and Y := supp(f 2 ). It can be shown [175] that every mass-preserving mapping v satisfies (in some sense)
div.formula: f 2 (v(x)) det(Dv(x)) = f 1 (x) ∀x ∈ X, v(X) ⊂ Y.
div.p: Letting A denote the set of mass-preserving mappings, the MK optimal transport problem is defined as seeking u ∈ A such that
div.formula: (5.3) u = argmin v∈A I(v) := R d c(x, v(x)) dμ 1 (x),
div.p: where c(x, y) is some given density of the cost functional I. The case c(x, y) = |x -y| p for p ≥ 1 is the most studied density and appears in many applications [3,175,176].

The connection between the MK problem and fully nonlinear second order PDEs lies in the fact that for certain convex density functions c (e.g., c(x, y) = |x -y| 2 ), the solution to (5.3) is unique and has a convex potential [28,175], that is, u = ∇ϕ for some convex function ϕ. In other words, ϕ satisfies
and u = ∇ϕ satisfies (5.3). Clearly, (5.4a) is a Monge-Ampère-type equation which serves as a constraint for the minimization problem (5.3).

To solve the minimization problem (5.3) by an iterative method, it is necessary to solve the Monge-Ampère-type constraint problem (5.4) at each iteration step, which is expensive and is indeed the bottleneck for the solution of the MK problem. As pointed out by Villani in [175, page xi], "Among topics which are still waiting for progress, let me mention the numerical methods for computing optimal transportation."

A few numerical methods have been proposed in the literature to solve the MK problem. Brenier and Benamou [21] proposed a continuum mechanics reformulation for the MK problem with the quadratic cost density function (i.e., p = 2); their method is based on minimizing the kinetic energy subject to the usual mass conservation law and the initial and final conditions for the density ρ. The reformulation was rigorously justified. The problem was then rewritten as a saddle point problem for some Lagrangian after the introduction of an (x, t)-dependent multiplier. The usual augmented Lagrangian method and solvers were used to solve the saddle point problem. At each gradient step, the main tasks consist of solving a Neumann problem for the Laplace equation and solving a convex minimization problem at each space-time grid point. Four numerical experiments concerning various mass transfer problems were presented and all numerical simulations seem satisfactory. In particular, it was shown numerically that the proposed numerical approach was able to find the optimal mass-preserving mapping from a periodic array of Gaussian densities to another one. Barrett and Prigozhin [13] proposed and analyzed a mixed formulation of the MK problem with L 1 cost density function (i.e., p = 1) based on the characterization of the optimality condition of [77]. A finite element approximation using the lowest order Raviart-Thomas element was then constructed and analyzed based on this mixed formulation. The proposed numerical method computes both the optimal transport density and the associated Kantorovich potential. Other computational algorithms Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php for MK problems were reported in [106,73]. The methodology based on the combination of the vanishing moment method and Galerkin-type discretization methods can certainly be used to solve the fully nonlinear constraint equation (5.4a), and such an approach has been proposed in [83,140,141]. We also refer the reader to [14,20] and the references therein for some recent numerical methods for unbalanced and partial MK problems.

div.head: Reconstruction of the Early Universe in Cosmology.
div.p: Constructing the deterministic past history of the universe from the knowledge of the present mass density field is a long standing and intensively studied problem in cosmology (cf. [90,137] and the references therein). A recently proposed Monge-Ampère-Kantorovich (MAK) approach [90,137,30,136,183] provides a promising mathematical formulation that could lead to the solution of the open problem (at least for certain types of universes, e.g., the Einstein-de Sitter universe). The new formulation requires solving fully nonlinear Monge-Ampère-type equations.
The governing equations for a flat, matter-dominated Einstein-de Sitter universe are the following Euler-Poisson equations:

where v(x, t) denotes the velocity (of the dark matter), ρ(x, t) denotes the density (normalized so that the background density is unity), and φ(x, t) is a gravitational potential. The variable x stands for the comoving spatial coordinates, and τ is the linear growth factor which is used as the time variable.
Setting τ → 0 in (5.5a) and (5.5c) yields v(x, 0) + ∇ x φ(x, 0) = 0, ρ(x, 0) = 1. (5.6) Alternatively, setting γ → 0 in (5.5a) gives the so-called Zel'dovich approximation (cf. [137]):
Let x(q, τ) be the comoving coordinates (or flow map) at time τ of a (dark matter) fluid particle that was initially located at q, i.e., x(q, 0) = q. Then it can be shown that
It is easy to check that x τ τ = 0, and (5.7) can be regarded as the Euler-Lagrange equation for the energy
where x 0 (q) := x(q, τ 0 ) for a fixed τ 0 > 0. Furthermore, from (5.8) 2 we have det ∂x 0 (q) ∂q = 1 ρ(x 0 (q)) . (5.9)

To summarize, the mathematical problem that needs to be solved can be described as follows: Given a density ρ and a fixed τ 0 > 0, find x 0 (q) := x(q, τ 0 ) such that x 0 satisfies (5.9) and minimizes the energy I 0 . This is exactly an MK optimal transport problem as discussed in section 5.4 with a quadratic cost density function. Therefore, all the numerical methods for the MK problem can be adapted to solve this reconstruction problem in cosmology. In particular, (5.9) can be converted into a Monge-Ampère-type equation by writing x 0 (q) = ∇ q Φ 0 (q) for some convex potential Φ 0 (q).

div.head: Optimal Transport and Image Registration.
div.p: Image registration is the process of establishing a common geometric frame of reference from two or more data sets from the same or different imaging modalities taken at different times. Multimodal registration proceeds in several steps. First, each image or data set to be matched should be individually calibrated, corrected from imaging distortions, and cleaned of noise and imaging artifacts. Next, a measure of dissimilarity between the data sets must be established, so the closeness of one image to another can be quantified after transformations are applied to them. Similarity measures proposed in the literature include the proximity of redefined landmarks, the distance between contours, and the difference between pixel intensity values. One can extract individual features that have to be matched in each data set. Once features have been extracted from each image, they must be paired with each other, then the similarity measure between the paired features can be formulated as an optimization problem (cf. [185] and the references therein).

During the past few decades, image acquisition devices have undergone rapid development and the huge number of images and their diverse types have attracted intensive research on methods and algorithms for automatic image registration. One such approach, which is closely related to the topic of this article, is based on the MK theory of optimal transport [107,108,184]. In this approach, each image frame is treated as a snapshot of some deformable "elastic body." The goal then becomes to determine the deformation using the properties of the "elastic material." One commonly used property is that of mass-preserving. Minimizing a cost functional, which quantifies the similarity measure between the paired features, among all mass-preserving mappings is exactly the MK optimal (mass) transport problem. As mentioned in section 5.4, for the L 2 cost functional the optimal mass-preserving mapping has a convex potential which satisfies a Monge-Ampère-type fully nonlinear PDE [175]. After having established this connection between image registration and the MK optimal transport, all the numerical methods and algorithms discussed in section 5.4 can be used to solve image registration problems.

div.head: Optimal
div.p: Transport and Mesh Adaptation. Mesh deformation has been the topic of mathematical research for many years and has gained extreme popularity lately as evidenced by the flux of publications [36,71,49,72,99,111,165,37]. The idea of mesh deformation is simple: redistribute a fixed number of mesh points, while preserving the mesh topology. A driving motivation for mesh deformation arises in the context of adaptive numerical methods, that is, r-adaptivity. In this approach, a fixed number of nodes are positioned to capture salient features of the computed Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php solutions such as shocks, moving interfaces, or other types of sharp variations of the solution and its derivatives. The construction of a deformed mesh can be determined by an invertible transformation, v, which maps a fixed computational domain X into a physical domain Y . A natural strategy for determining v is based on the concept of optimal transport described in section 5.4. The idea is natural, that is, to construct a mass-preserving mapping v such that the resulting mesh is nearest to a uniform mesh. Intuitively, the use of optimal transport to construct meshes is proper, as meshes close to uniform are less likely to have thin and tangled grids, a crucial property in numerical computations. Furthermore, meshes obtained by the optimal transport criteria are irrotational (since curlv = curl∇ϕ = 0 for some convex scalar ϕ), an often desired property of mesh deformation mappings. As explained in section 5.4, the computation of v reduces to solving a Monge-Ampère-type PDE f 2 (∇ϕ) det(D 2 ϕ) = f 1 , where f 1 , f 2 : R d → R are given. As a result, all of the numerical methods designed for the MK problem can be used for mesh adaptation.

div.head: A Fully Nonlinear Semigeostrophic Flow
div.p: Model. Semigeostrophic flows refer to slowly varying air and water flows in the troposphere (i.e., near the earth surface) constrained by rotation and stratification. A widely used model in meteorology for semigeostrophic flows, proposed by Hoskins [110], is

where Ω ⊂ R 3 , ∇ H := (∂ x1 , ∂ x2 , 0), and D t := ∂ t + u • ∇ denotes the material derivative, u g := -f -1 (∂ x2 p, -∂ x1 p, 0), u ⊥ = (u 2 , -u 1 , 0), f denotes the Coriolis constant, and g stands for the gravitational acceleration constant. The above semigeostrophic flow equations are an approximation of the Boussinesq equations and are thought to be an efficient model to describe front formation (cf. [63,62,61,134]).

Under certain assumptions and in some appropriately chosen curvilinear coordinates (called "dual space"), Benamou and Brenier [19] (see also [62,86,132]) showed that the Hoskins semigeostrophic flow equations can be formulated as the following coupled system consisting of the fully nonlinear Monge-Ampère equation and the transport equation:

, where α is the density of a probability measure on R 3 and ψ * denotes the Legendre transform of a convex function (called the geopotential) ψ. Note that α, ψ * , v are nonprimitive physical variables.

The numerical approximation of (5.11) is challenging. In addition to the obvious difficulty of the full nonlinearity of (5.11a), the problem has two more difficulties. First, the equations are posed on an unbounded domain, which makes solving the Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php system numerically infeasible. Second, the unusual boundary condition (5.11d) is hard to handle numerically. The work of [86] is perhaps the only numerical work reported in the literature for problem (5.11). By exploiting the compact support property of solutions of (5.11) proved in [19], the approach of [86] is to solve (5.11a)-(5.11c) on a truncated finite computational domain and to substitute the boundary condition (5.11d) with an easy-to-handle "absorbing boundary condition." Moreover, the vanishing moment method is applied to the Monge-Ampère equation (5.11a) to overcome the difficulty caused by the full nonlinearity. Finally, a fully discrete modified characteristic finite element method is developed for the vanishing moment approximation problem. It is proved that the proposed fully discrete finite element method converges with an optimal order rate of convergence.

div.head: A Semigeostrophic Wind Problem.
div.p: The semigeostrophic wind problem under consideration is concerned with determining the wind velocity field from a (given) pressure field that can be constructed using remotely sensed temperature data. The velocity and pressure of the wind are assumed to be governed by the following so-called f -plane momentum equations (cf. [109,155]):
div.formula: u t -νΔu + (u • ∇)u + ∇p = f u ⊥ , div u = 0.
div.p: As in section 5.8, u ⊥ = (u 2 , -u 1 ) in the two-dimensional case and u ⊥ = (u 2 , -u 1 , 0) in the three-dimensional case, and f denotes the Coriolis constant.

Suppose that d = 2. Then taking the divergence in the first equation and using the second equation yields Let ψ be a streamline function of u, that is, u = (∇ψ) ⊥ = (∂ x2 ψ, -∂ x1 ψ). Substituting ψ into (5.12) and noting div u = 0 gives the following nonlinear balance equation:
(5.13) 2det(D 2 ψ) + f Δψ = Δp.
Thus, the problem is reduced to solving the Monge-Ampère-type equation (5.13) for a given pressure p.

It is easy to show [141] that (5.13) can be converted into the Monge-Ampère equation using a simple change of dependent variables. The difficulty with (5.13) is that the equation may lose ellipticity for some pressure fields, which occurs when the right-hand side of the converted Monge-Ampère equation becomes negative or changes sign. In that case, there is no PDE theory to guarantee the existence of solutions. The practice adopted in the meteorology literature for overcoming the difficulty is to preprocess the pressure data such that the processed data makes (5.13) elliptic (cf. [109,155] and the references therein). Clearly, the practice is very ad hoc and the processed data may produce large errors in the computed velocity field. A few numerical works have been proposed and used in the meteorological community. Due to the difficulty associated with numerically solving the Monge-Ampère equation, most of these methods are ad hoc (cf. [169] and the references therein). On the other hand, we note that the vanishing moment method and finite element methods have recently been developed in [141]. In particular, the vanishing moment method allows one to compute moment solutions for "nonelliptic" pressure data. where E tx [y(t)] stands for the expectation of the process y(t), L is the running cost, and g is the terminal cost. A typical stochastic optimal control problem is concerned with minimizing J(t, x, u) for each (t, x) over all u ∈ U (cf. [88,119]).

To describe Bellman's dynamic programming approach [18] for the stochastic optimal control problem, let u * ∈ U be a minimizer for a fixed (x, t) that is, u * (t, x) ∈ argmin u∈U J(t, x, u), and define the value function
div.formula: V (t, x) = J(t, x, u * ).
div.p: That is, V is the minimal cost achieved starting from the initial value x(t) = x and u * is the optimal control that attains the minimum. Using the Bellman (dynamic programming) principle, it can be shown that V satisfies the following Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation (cf. [88,119]):
V t = inf u∈U 1 2 tr A(t, x, u)D 2 x V + f (t, x, u) • ∇ x V + L(t, x, u) ,

where A = σσ T , V t , ∇ x V , and D 2 x V denote, respectively, the time derivative, the gradient, and the Hessian with respect to the variable x. Thus, the original stochastic control problem is reduced to the problem of solving the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation (5.14), which is a fully nonlinear second order PDE.

There is a large amount of literature on numerical (mainly finite difference) methods for the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman equation (5.14) and its time-independent counterpart. We refer the reader to section 2.1.4 for a review of these finite difference methods and to [82] for some latest development in Galerkin-type numerical methods based on the vanishing moment methodology. It should be noted that the infinity-Laplace equation is not fully nonlinear, but rather quasi-linear. Still, its nondivergence form, degeneracy, and strong nonlinearity in the Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php first order derivatives make the infinity-Laplace equation as difficult as fully nonlinear PDEs to analyze and approximate (cf. [23,78,145,144]).

Similar to the situation of fully nonlinear second order PDEs, the infinity-Laplace equation has been extensively studied in the recent years, and it has a well-established viscosity solution theory [6,23,15,16,57,78,116]. On the other hand, very little progress on developing numerical methods for the infinity-Laplace equation has been made so far. The first numerical work was reported in [145], where a monotone finite difference scheme was constructed and proved to fulfill the convergence criterion of [12]. The only other reported numerical works on the infinity-Laplace equation are [84,83], where numerical methods based on the vanishing moment methodology combined with finite element and mixed finite element methods were constructed and analyzed.

div.head: Concluding Remarks.
div.p: In this article we have presented a review of recent developments in numerical methods for fully nonlinear second order PDEs. Various aspects of this class of PDEs have been discussed in the article, which range from the solution concepts, the main numerical challenges, and successful and unsuccessful approaches to their applications in science and engineering. Our focus is to present different discretization techniques in the literature for this difficult class of PDEs in a concise and easy-to-follow fashion, while related references are given for further reading for the interested reader. Another message we hope we have conveyed in this review is that there is a very strong interplay between PDE analysis and numerical analysis for fully nonlinear second order PDEs. As is the case for linear and quasilinear PDEs, the PDE analysis and theory provide the guidelines and theoretical foundation for developing reliable and efficient numerical methods. On the other hand, numerical solutions and techniques as well as the power of numerical computations provide evidence and hints for discovering and proving better analytical results. This interplay is enhanced for fully nonlinear second order PDEs. The search for reliable and efficient numerical methods not only leads to many difficult and interesting PDE problems, but also expands the boundaries of PDE solution concepts.

From the relatively large number of works reviewed in this article and from the fact that most of them have appeared very recently, it is clear that research on numerical methods for fully nonlinear second order PDEs has garnered a lot of attention and interest in recent years. Significant progress in both developing new discretization methods and solving real world application problems has been made for this class of difficult problems due to these collective efforts. On the other hand, as a new subarea within numerical PDEs, there are many issues and problems which remain to be addressed and solved, of which we mention the following few.

As pointed out in section 1.2, the viscosity (weak) solution concept is nonvariational. Instead, it is based on a "differentiation by parts approach." Such a weak solution does not satisfy the underlying PDE in a tangible sense unless the solution is sufficiently regular. An interesting and difficult question is whether it is possible to develop a constructive discrete analogue of the viscosity solution concept and theory (we may call it "a discrete differentiation by parts approach"). If such a discrete analogue could be developed, it might lead to the construction of more efficient numerical methods for fully nonlinear second order PDEs, as the construction is closely guided by and faithfully follows the PDE theory.

It was emphasized in section 1.4 that no matter which discretization method is used, the resulting algebraic systems are expected to be highly nonlinear due to the full nonlinearity of the underlying PDEs. Solving such a highly nonlinear algebraic system is a challenging problem. In particular, since nonuniqueness and conditional Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22. Redistribution subject to SIAM license or copyright; see http://www.siam.org/journals/ojsa.php uniqueness are common for fully nonlinear PDEs, the resulting algebraic systems are expected to inherit that nonuniqueness. A successful application of the Newton method requires the availability of a sufficiently good initial guess. How to obtain such a good initial guess is often left unaddressed in the literature, but in many cases providing it can be as difficult as solving the nonlinear algebraic system itself. Consequently, developing robust and efficient fast solvers (such as multigrid and domain decomposition algorithms) becomes a vitally important issue for the solution of fully nonlinear second order PDEs.

The vanishing moment method discussed in section 4 provides and promises a general systematic approach for numerically solving general fully nonlinear second order PDEs. While its application domain has continued to expand [86,83,82,141], rigorous proofs of its convergence in most applications still lag behind, and important issues such as "boundary layers" and rates of convergence in a general setting remain to be addressed.

As it is seen in sections 2-4, some numerical methods reviewed in this article are heuristic. Although numerical experiments show the good performance and promise of the methods, rigorous convergence analysis of these methods remains an open problem. Obviously, such a convergence analysis is not only important but also necessary. Without a doubt, the anticipated convergence analysis is expected to be difficult (at least not easy) because the standard techniques used for analyzing the convergence of numerical methods for linear and quasi-linear PDEs either do not work or do not directly carry over to the fully nonlinear case. Nonstandard and new techniques must be developed to do the job, as exhibited in [12,31,32,85,86,87,83,122,147]. It would be extremely desirable to develop a general convergence analysis framework (and a set of new techniques) to serve as a blueprint for carrying out the convergence analysis when a numerical method is constructed.

Finally, there are many fully nonlinear second order PDE problems that have been either untouched or lightly studied from a numerical viewpoint. Among them, we mention parabolic Monge-Ampère equations and general fully nonlinear second order parabolic PDEs [130, Chapters XIV and XV], k-surface equations [174], systems of fully nonlinear second order PDEs, and degenerate and nonelliptic fully nonlinear PDEs [50,155,169]. As expected, all these problems are very difficult to solve numerically. Their complicated and peculiar structures make them difficult to discretize, and the lack of a well-developed PDE (weak) solution theory makes matters even worse.

XIAOBING FENG, ROLAND GLOWINSKI, AND MICHAEL NEILAN Theorem 4.1 (cf. [83]). Let Ω = B R (0) ⊂ R d (d ≥ 2), the ball centered at the origin with radius R. Suppose g| ∂Ω = const and f = f (r) with r = |x| satisfying f ∈ C 0 ((0, R)) and f ≥ 0 a.e. in (0, R). Then (4.6) has a unique monotone increasing classical radial solution u ε = u ε (r). Moreover, Δu ε := u ε rr + d-1 r u ε r > 0 in (0, R) for all ε > 0. Furthermore, for any r 0 ∈ (0, R), there exists an ε 0 > 0 such that Δu ε (r) > ε for all r ∈ (r 0 , R) and ε ∈ (0, ε 0 ). Theorem 4.1 contains the main results of Theorems 3.8 and 3.9 of [83]. We remark that the positivity of Δu ε plays a vital role in the whole convergence analysis of u ε . First, it enables us to obtain crucial uniform (in ε) and sharp a priori estimates for u ε ; see [83,Theorem 3.11]. Second, it suggests that u ε may be a convex function itself, which was hoped for but not expected initially. That is indeed the case as described in the following theorem.
Theorem 4.2 (cf. Theorem 3.12 of [83]). In addition to the assumptions of Theorem 4.1, suppose there exists a positive constant

then there exist a monotone decreasing sequence {s j } j≥0 ⊂ (0, R) and two corresponding sequences, namely, {ε j } j≥0 ⊂ (0, 1), which is also monotone deceasing, and {r * j } j≥0 ⊂ (0, R) satisfying s j 0 + as j → ∞, and u ε rr (s j ) ≥ 0 and Rr * j = O(ε) such that for each j ≥ 0, u ε is strictly convex in (s j , r * j ) for all ε ∈ (0, ε j ). Part (i) of the above theorem says that in the two-and three-dimensional cases, u ε is either strictly convex in the whole domain Ω or it is "almost" strictly convex in the sense that it is strictly convex in Ω minus an ε-neighborhood of ∂Ω. This possible ε-neighborhood of ∂Ω is exactly the boundary layer which was mentioned in section 4.1. The (surprising) convexity property of u ε shows one of the advantages of the vanishing moment method and explains why the method works efficiently in practice, as it has a built-in mechanism for selecting the "right" solution (i.e., the convex solution). Since the limit of a sequence of convergent convex functions is also a convex function, the vanishing moment method is able to find an inside track for approximating the unique convex viscosity solution of the Monge-Ampère problem and eliminates the daunting challenge of handling the conditional uniqueness of the problem at the discrete level. Moreover, the precise information about the boundary layer has a significant (numerical) consequence because it can be exploited to design an iterative surgical strategy to improve the accuracy of the computed solutions (see below and [83,Chapter 7] for more discussions in this direction). Part (ii) of the theorem essentially states that the results of part (i) still hold in four and higher dimensions provided that ε is sufficiently small.
The above two theorems and the a priori estimates proved in [83,Theorem 3.11] then lead to the following convergence results.

Theorem 4.3 (cf. Theorem 3.13 of [83]). Suppose the assumptions of Theorem 4.2 still hold. Let u denote the unique convex (classical or viscosity) solution to problem (4.5) and u ε be the monotone increasing classical solution to problem (4.6) proved in Theorem 4.1. Then the following hold:

(i) u 0 = lim ε→0 + u ε exists pointwise and u ε converges to u 0 uniformly in every compact subset of (0, R) as ε → 0 + . Moreover, u 0 is strictly convex in every compact subset, in particular, in every subinterval of [0, R]. Downloaded 05/21/13 to 146.201.208.22.
